149612332.review:
I played KotOR about 10 years after its initial release, because I had been told it was "like Dragon Age".
And indeed, it is very much a Bioware RPG XD

It has many of the good points I enjoy from games like that : companions that react to your decisions and may leave or turn on you, choices that have consequences further along the story, and several endings depending on what you did. The story seems straightforward but has a few plot twists you may or may not see coming depending on how much attention you pay to what is going on.

I liked that your attitude does not only influence the story, but also your character : there are different powers for Light- and Dark-aligned characters. (I'd say Light has more utility and Dark more DPS, but let's not forget the ultimate Light power : droid destruction. Absolute game changer.)

And well, at the time there weren't that many Star Wars games, especially if like me you're only interested in Jedi and lightsabers XD So being able to play a Force-sensitive lightsaber wielder was a great experience at the time.

The one criticism I have is that Jedi powers and lightsabers are so powerful that it's hard to justify taking any non-Jedi companion over Jedi ones, limiting your options. But the game is not too difficult so you can probably succeed with any party composition.

I fear the game has aged a lot (as I haven't touched it in the last 10 years), and it's not as deep as more recent RPG, but I think it's worth a try if you like the genre.

149612022.review: An all time classic and one of my favorite games of all time. The characters are all pretty good, the maps are fun, the quests and side quests are all fun. The ending is surprising the first time i played it. And the different possible ending and play styles make this a game i have played through countless times. The two main criticisms i have are that the game are that it will crash sometimes or get in a state where i have to go back to the last save to proceed. The second one is that, despite my prior statement about the different play styles, having your main character be blaster focused makes the game incredible hard, if not impossible. Despite those complaints, I would highly recommend this game if you willing to put up with the graphics.

149177271.review: This game is a nostalgia hype vacation trap, you know where someone builds their identity out of "having experienced it" but in reality it was an excruciatingly agonizing series of dissappointments. "KOTOR is a great game" is what people force themselves to believe in the same way that coworker or family member spent years telling you about that great vacation adventure they had been planning on taking for years. The reality of the experience is so embarassing compared to the hype theyve been putting into it, that it is easier for them to continue the lie than let everyone know how fucking stupid thevye been for promoting it. Of course, then new people buy into the adventure as well, only to suffer the same result. How fortunate you are that I am brave enough to withstand the fanboy deniers and tell you that "KOTOR is a fucking awful game that no one should play". The plot you can find in any childrens book; the combat is a dementia's porting of DnD rulesets salvaged from bioware's neverwinternights spagetti code. But youve heard such great things? surely i am just a bad gamer. Imagine playing a character with 5 hitpoints, and the other characters you fight do 18 damage attacks (inquiring minds might like to know that the game has a descriptive combat log). Difficulty setting is just a question as to how many times you want to endure save-loading. I could write more, but KOTOR 2 finished downloading, and KOTOR is not a game worth any attention. I'd rather sit in an abandoned prison for eternity than play KOTOR on the computer inside it. I'd keep my sanity longer that way.

147522504.review:
A Galactic Triumph: Star Wars Knights of the Old Republic Review

Star Wars Knights of the Old Republic (KOTOR) is a true masterpiece that immerses players in the captivating Star Wars universe, offering an unforgettable journey through its rich lore and compelling characters. Despite a few hiccups, this game stands as a testament to the magic of a galaxy far, far away.

One of the game's undeniable strengths lies in its ability to recreate the immersive Star Wars atmosphere. From the moment you step into the vast, intricately designed worlds, you are transported into a universe filled with the iconic sounds of blaster fire, the hum of lightsabers, and the epic musical score that has become synonymous with Star Wars. KOTOR brilliantly captures the essence of the franchise, making every moment a nostalgic delight for fans.

The characters and side missions in KOTOR are nothing short of exceptional. Each character is beautifully crafted with depth and personality, making them more than just mere companions. The side missions, too, are a highlight, offering players a chance to delve into the diverse stories and histories of the galaxy. These elements contribute to a gaming experience that goes beyond the main storyline, enriching the overall narrative.

The combat system in KOTOR is both fun and engaging. The strategic elements of turn-based combat, combined with the thrill of wielding a lightsaber or firing a blaster, create an experience that remains true to the spirit of Star Wars. The variety of Force powers and skills add layers of complexity, ensuring that combat never becomes monotonous.

At its core, KOTOR is undeniably a true Star Wars game. The narrative weaves a tale of epic proportions, filled with twists, turns, and moral ambiguity. The choices you make as a player shape the destiny of the galaxy, mirroring the impactful decision-making seen in the Star Wars movies. The main story is a captivating journey that fans and newcomers alike will appreciate.

However, it's essential to acknowledge the game's shortcomings. KOTOR does suffer from a few bugs that can occasionally disrupt the flow of gameplay. The user interface, while functional, could benefit from improvements to enhance the overall gaming experience. Additionally, the game's pace can be a bit slow, especially with a fair amount of back-and-forth walking, which might test the patience of some players.

Despite these drawbacks, KOTOR remains a highly entertaining experience. With its captivating Star Wars ambiance, well-developed characters, engaging combat, and an epic main story, it earns a solid 8 out of 10. The imperfections do little to diminish the overall enjoyment of a game that successfully captures the magic of Star Wars in a galaxy of its own.

Ok, I know the game was released in 2003, but this absolutely deserves a play in my humbly correct opinion. if you can get past the clunkiness and aged graphics then you're in for an absolute treat.

Almost all aspects of the game are enjoyable, but the stand-out merits of the game are it's gripping story, compelling characters, flexible morality system and intriguing universe. The themes explored in this game are, if you look a bit deeper, often quite depressing and they genuinely felt like the real daily struggles of the people inhabiting the Star Wars galaxy. The game is obviously considerably technologically limited, yet every planet still feels like a real adventure to explore. it's absolutely incredible how they've managed to really capture the essence and mood of each location with such little to work with.

the final reason to play this game is Jolee Bido. He is an absolute standout side character, and while I won't spoil too much, I will leave you with this quote:
       "Love doesn't lead to the dark side. Passion can lead to rage and fear, and can be controlled... but passion is not the same thing as love. Controlling your passions while being in love... that's what they should teach you to beware. But love itself will save you, not condemn you."
       -Jolee Bindo

146493789.review:
Easily one of the greatest single player games ever made and a top 5 story told within the Star Wars universe (canon or not). It took me a long time to get around to this game but I'm glad I finally did. My only major complaint is one that is shared amongst most fans and critics of the game: the combat. Even for early-2000's standards, the combat is pretty wonky, but it is something you can look past in the grand scheme of things. Otherwise, the game is perfect and still feels engaging this many years later. Every single character is written so well and they all have such unique and interesting stories, making the long stretches of dialogue feel worthwhile and important, with every conversation carrying choices with outcomes that can impact the story in several ways. The environments you can explore are diverse across the several planets and ships you'll have access to, and you even have the freedom to choose the order in which you complete them, making each playthrough that much more unique. With these characters and worlds, the game presents its best and most celebrated aspect: the story. KOTOR's campaign can be experienced in a multitude of different ways and lengths, with areas being filled with side quests you can do to enrich the story and learn more about your companions, and different engagements whether you are taking the light or dark side path.

(SPOILER ALERT)

Part of this story includes not only the best part of the game, but one of the most iconic moments in video game, or even storytelling history. This moment I'm referring to is the climactic plot twist. Throughout the whole game, your character suffers from amnesia and cannot remember who they are. In the background, 2 fallen Jedi (Revan and Malak), wage war on the Republic. In the climax of the story, the player is revealed to have been Revan the entire time. This twist is delivered in such a fantastic way, and can immensely impact the relationship you have with your companions depending on the route you take.

Even though a remake is coming (?), I believe this is a game that everyone should experience at least once. When on sale this game gets as cheap as like 0.99 USD so why not?

146198324.review:
There are a lot of things one can say about KotOR. Many consider it to be the greatest Star Wars game that currently exists, and I am inclined to agree. While not perfect, Revan's original adventure across the galaxy far away told an even longer time ago stands the test of time, and remains a must play for any Star Wars enthusiast.

The story told in KotOR is a captivating one.  It's a simple tale; an amnesiac awakening into circumstances far beyond their understanding eventually learning their role in the greater story and taking their destiny into their own hands. The actual contents of the story aren't necessarily original in concept, but the game's execution of this plot is what makes it so powerful. KotOR exceeds in building an enticing mystery around Revan's identity and history that you get to see unfurl alongside your character in play. Furthermore, the game offers an interesting and often fun supporting cast to experience the adventure alongside you. This, alongside Revan's history with the main antagonist, helps the story gain a sense of personality and personal stakes that elevate the whole experience. It's no wonder that the story, alongside the major additions to Star Wars history this game developed with the Infinite Empire, pioneered an entire era of lore for the series expanded upon by various later media. So iconic is KotOR's story that the Old Republic is an easy third to the Imperial and Clone Wars eras in terms of media focus, and for good reason.

The roleplaying mechanics of KotOR were also ahead of their time, with letting players sway their moral alignment outcomes of conversations with what they say and do. Although fairly primitive compared to later games in this field, KotOR set the major groundwork for such choose-your-own-adventure style gameplay that Bioware themselves would continue in later Old Republic games and their iconic Mass Effect series. Given Revan's history as both Jedi and Sith, allowing the player a chance at either redemption or descent plays a huge role in the power of this game's experience. This is especially powerful since your moral choices directly impact the effectiveness of abilities available to Revan as you grow. Though, as a Dark Side enthusiast myself, I wish some of this game's evil options felt less comical. Some options within dialogue and quests can get pretty goofy with how openly ruthless you're allowed to become, and generally the Dark Side experience can feel lackluster compared to the more canonical Light Side one, which likely received significantly more focus. This can be a bit dissuading from the feeling of choice the morality system is intended to provide, but that doesn't diminish what replayability and variety it gives each playthrough.

KotOR's combat and leveling should feel quite familar to tabletop fans. Heavily relying on 3.5 D&D rules for stats and leveling, KotOR might be a bit intimidating to progress in for those less experienced in the style of play. Personally I feel this combat is the game's weakest aspect, as in most fights it becomes very easy to just let the combat automatically play out while you occasionally activate abilities at opportune moments and just pray they land. hitchance and round-based combat can work well, as shown by more concurrent smash hits like Baldur's Gate III, but I don't think KotOR managed to do this system much justice. Particularly on the Steam port I ran, I also had frequent issues with whichever character I was controlling just stopping mid-movement and refusing to progress until I swapped characters, occasionally even in combat. It's a workable system overall, but definitely lacking compared to other focuses of the game.

Regardless of all that, however, there is a key factor that I think is why KotOR really stands as the best Star Wars game. By far, it succeeds the most at recapturing the feel of the Original Trilogy in a video game format. Through a combination of its fun writing, orchestral backing music, charming visuals, and more, KotOR feels like it truly belongs in Star Wars, in a way few other games in the series ever could. Words can't really do this point justice, so just experience the game yourself to really feel this point lmao.

Overall, KotOR is a certified classic. It has a solid amount to offer to RPG fans, and much more for Star Wars fans. If you have any interest in this game whatsoever, do yourself a favor and pick it up. You won't regret it.

145684324.review:
This is an interesting Star Wars RPG and it has decent character development, you get a lot of character lore throughout the game and learn a lot about the history of the world plus you can dual wield lightsabers so bonus points from me. All of the characters are interesting and what I like is that none of them were irrelevant or forgettable to me. I enjoyed about 80% of the game, then for the last 2 or 3 areas it feels like everything is rushed, watered down, and worse quality. I felt unsatisfied at the end of the game and was thinking “that’s all?”.  The combat is alright, it’s nothing special and I don’t think it’s that fun since it gets boring to just click spam the entire time and watch your characters miss every 2 seconds. This made the last dungeon miserable because it’s literally full of endless enemy waves.

However, I cannot in good conscience give this game more than a 5/10. I have only one word to describe my experience in this game. CRASHING. The game will crash at any time. Before or after scripted cutscenes, or for no reason at all. It wasn’t that bad for most of the game, some crashes here and there but not much. But oh boy, toward the end it was crashing and bugs galore. Be prepared to save every 5 mins or less because you’ll risk losing your progress and maybe even corrupting your save like what happened to me. My save got corrupted so I had to spend 20+ minutes killing the same enemy waves all over again. Also, sometimes you have to reload saves to redo some parts because the game won’t progress like it’s supposed to. Best Star Wars game by far. Honestly it's probably my number one favorite piece of Star Wars media even including the movies. A fantastic story line, great characters, and that pure sense of Star Wars wonder. If you're a Star Wars fan this game is an absolute must play. It may be old (20 years this November!) but it absolutely stands the test of time. I've played this game many times over the years, from my first time when I'd meet my friend at the bus stop and we'd talk excitedly about how far we had gotten, to now when I like to just boot it up, swing my lightsaber, mess with Carth, and listen to HK-47 call me a meatbag. 

Also I HIGHLY recommend playing as a female. The banter and romance with Carth is just infinitely more entertaining than Bastilla. You can also find the secret way to romance Juhani (you will need a guide though, if you click one wrong dialogue the romance is locked). 145014684.review:
So I think I should start this review by specifying that while I have very little time with the steam version I have played this game at least half a dozen times and finished it most of the times, on that later.
As you can see I do not think this is a very good game. I hope to convince you of it, though it still might be worth playing if it's on sale.

Let's start with general overview. This is an RPG using DnD's dice throw systems, these happen automatically whenever player preforms an action behind the scenes with random number generators.

I think I shall list the positives first as the list is quite short. Note that these are positives without reservations.
1) game is inovative in the genere. Mainly due to the camera system.
2) there seemed to be a generaly well meaning attempt to immerse player into star wars
That's it for the positives.
Neutral things
1) soundtrack is quite good (for the most part) however not very cohesive and can sometimes feel all over the place
2) visuals while not excelent (and certainly not using the engine to the fullest potencial as attested by the sequel) are still pretty good for 2003 game
3) combat system is serviceable (with addendums in negative section)
4) not terribly difficulit but not completely mindless either
Now onto the negative list and oh boy there's lot
1) B U G S all over the fucking game. On my disc I managed to permanently glitch the big shark to the other side of the bridge. On steam the game started to crash around star forge and several times I just got stuck on geometry and had to reset.
2) story is garbage. 1 counted them, 1 good character (Jolee my man). Rest of them are confusing mess, unfurfuilled potential or unintentionally self inserts of anyone with even a sliver of critical thinking (looking at ya Carth). The worldbuilding is as broken as they come with groundbreaking technologies that fuck up the continuity of the universe and plot that relies on galaxy being in fucking stasis to make any goddamn sense.
3) morality system is garbage. It's be such an angel you are compromising everything for no reason, or be the dastardly saturday morning cartoon villain. What a joke.
4) HIDEN FUCKING STATS. Oh you were building your character expecting lever 35+ because we gave you almost no indication where the lever cealing is? Well fuck you now you're at the endgame with level 20 and no usefull combat stats for the final fight. Fuck you. Oh you were building blaster character, well have you considered that wrong you are jedi and get less point for your traits. Better luck next time bucko. This is omnipresent and annoying as shit. In turned based RPG I need to know what my stats are BIOWARE!!!
5) Inventory is hard to navigate lunacy made by someone who really likes inventory management simulators.
6) most builds barely viable

I could ramble on but in general. It's an overhyped mess fueled by nostalgia

144123168.review:
The Star Wars universe is a delight to traverse through, with all the different planets and settings it has to offer, even it being a 2003 game, the aesthetics are appreciated. That being said KOTOR is in dire need of some form of a graphical upgrade, being the type of game it is (with open spaces and many interesting backgrounds) I was constantly looking around observing the world around me, albeit with limited controls (being able to move the screen left to right). 

Being a Bioware game though, the characters and story are written really well, with just a few hiccups, especially where the old conflicting Jedi vs Sith ideologies are concerned, which I felt mostly lacked depth. The companions in particular are this game's shining achievement, and could be a contender for best party members in any RPG. You really do get attached to them, and no member of the 'Ebon Hawk' is alike.

The combat is hit or miss however. It is undoubtedly a deep system with all the different Dice rolls behind the scenes and a large canvas for players to do lots of character builds. I personally found it fun, but it wasn't something flashy.

144030049.review: in terms of roleplaying mechanics, choice, customization, and balance this game is one of the best. however as it is an old one you can clearly see its age even after heavily modding the game. the story itself is compelling and the characters are more or less interesting although the writing proves to be primitive at some points which can be attributed to the game's age. interestingly many similarities between this game and mass effect can be found which demonstrate the bioware design philosophy. if you are intending to mod the game and play it for its value as a pioneering 3d rpg then this is a good option for you. otherwise wait for the remake or try something else.

143691051.review:
When launched it was one of the best star wars games out there, and now 20 years later it still is. welcome to a competent, compelling, wonderfully scored, easy to learn hard to master, highly memorable, and utterly bloat free RPG. its also highly quotable as you can tell by reading some of the other reviews.

it has minor issues in regards to cut-scenes having difficulty initiating playback, poor pathing for your party (pretty normal for 2003), and I had a bug where your character wouldn't move after combat (Its cased by to high a frame rate, or so I think, I fixed it by turning VFX on, fixes vary).

I finished my latest run in a tad under 40 hours, for the new player it will likely be between 40 and 50 to 100% the game. this makes it a nice full experience without having to commit 100's of hours into finishing every single stupid jump off every tower and find all 200 hidden feathers side quests. its 40 hours of meat, with little fat. 

the community is still highly active and mostly spoiler free build advice can be easily found. the Reddit page has a no spoilers rule so its a good place to go if you need help with bugs or figuring out a build.

still looks pretty good today despite its lower res textures and limited polygons. also the computer cheats at pazaak. you have been warned.

143591775.review: An absolute CLASSIC Star Wars game. The story of KOTOR takes place 4000 years before the movies, following a young republic trooper who learns they are capable of using the force, learning to become a Jedi and facing a galaxy wide threat. This premise is perfect, and really makes you feel like you are a part of the universe. When you first crash on Taris you are a nobody, you share a small hideout with a surviving officer, and stepping out onto that first planet is truly jaw dropping. Everything in this game makes you feel truly immersed, the music, the world building, the minor npcs that you interact with on each planet, its all just perfect. Speaking of planets, the game strikes the perfect balance between old and new, letting you explore beloved planets from past movies while also introducing you to brand new ones. The plot is also spot on, showing your characters journey from a simple soldier to a hero of the Jedi order- or its doom. KOTOR lets YOU decide whether you want to be a hero or a villain, letting your custom character make various light and dark side decisions that will effect those around you, forcing you to make a major decision towards the end of the game. All I can say is avoid spoilers at ALL COSTS, because you will not want to have your experience of the amazing storyline ruined by spoilers. The only thing I could critique would be the combat system, it can feel pretty dated at times and you shouldn't go into KOTOR expecting combat like The Force Unleashed or Fallen Order, but once you get used to it (if you even had a problem with it in the first place) then you should be fine. And at the end of the day, the story, world building and pure immersion make up for any tiny flaw that you may encounter while playing.

I believe this game still holds up today with the mods installed. I had fun running through it again after all these years.

Oh my..it's been a journey. After playing this game as a kid back in 2003 i thought it was time to pick it up and finally finish Knights Of The Old Republic, and to better understand it as a Star Wars fan. 

I started out by tracking down the best updates and mods to flesh out the game more for modern systems and the modding community for KotOR on reddit did not disappoint. It took a long time, but by the time I had everything up and running I was so happy. Ran at 240hz, better textures, quality of life and all that. 

The game was honestly better than I remembered. There is such a large amount of life and love in this games universe. I tried to do damn near everything and do a light run with some dark side antics. It took me 50 hours but I managed to do it. I completed KotOR. The story is awesome as a star wars fan and even if you aren't if you haven't had this game spoiled then PLAY IT. The ride is absolutely worth it. 

My main (and only) complaints are just the amount of random things I would get stuck on and had to quicksave and reload. Also one of my mods broke my dialog stuff for part of the end of [spoiler] Taris before the swoop race. [/spoiler] Where I had to warp through a door. No biggy, took like 5 minutes to bypass, and was my fault to begin with. The final complaint is spoiler stuff: [spoiler] the whole last two fights, with the droids and Malek are ridiculous. [/spoiler] Who on earth thought it was a good idea to stretch those out for longer time? Was just frustrating, but it was relieving to finally finish.

I'm going to surface this by saying that I've played KOTOR before on Xbox. I have about 50 hours in that, so don't let the 10 hours on here fool you, was mostly curious about mods, but that's besides the point.

**MILD SPOILER WARNING**

What a fucking masterpiece. It's got issues here and there, but all classics do. Taris might drag a bit, but once you're up and out of there, it's so worth it. The worlds are excellent, the characters are great (especially HK-47, my favorite droid), their storylines are so fun (and as a side note, I'm so glad that there is canon queer representation in the form of Juhani and FemC, especially in a Star Wars game this old) I enjoy the combat system more than I remember, and it is absolutely gorgeous despite the outdated graphics. Additionally, I love the soundtrack. I always love hearing the character creation/main theme and it's different forms, the intense opening music onboard the Endar Spire, the unique themes for different planets, especially that absolutely gorgeous track for the planet Manaan/Ahto City, and when everything is tied up and you face Darth Malak, I'd go nearly as far as to say it's as good as Duel of the Fates.

The lore is absolutely amazing and I've always loved the Old Republic era. From Force Bonds to the Mandalorian wars to the Rakatan Infinite Empire and the Star Forge. (And I will always appreciate how much SWTOR builds on the lore of KOTOR, but that's a story for another review that's way too long.)

KOTOR may look and in some areas feel outdated, but comparing the negatives to the positives is like comparing a piece of coal to a diamond. I'd recommend it for any Star Wars fan.

Title: Star Wars: Knights of the Old Republic - A Brief Review

"Star Wars: Knights of the Old Republic (KOTOR) is a noteworthy title in the realm of RPGs and the Star Wars franchise.

Positive Aspects:

Immersive Storytelling: The game's branching storyline is captivating, and the moral choices impacting your alignment with the Force offer replay value.
Engaging Combat: KOTOR’s blend of real-time and turn-based combat provides strategic depth, keeping battles interesting and engaging.
Iconic Music: The soundtrack, reminiscent of the Star Wars films, enhances the game's atmosphere.
Negative Aspects:

Dated Graphics(it's not so important): Although charming, the game's visual quality is noticeably outpaced by modern standards.
Some Gameplay Mechanics: Certain mechanics, such as inventory management and pathfinding, can feel somewhat clunky and outdated.
In summary, despite some dated aspects, KOTOR's rich story, strategic combat, and Star Wars charm make it a timeless classic worth experiencing."

142295498.review:
[h1] Star Wars: Knights of the Old Republic - The Gold Standard of RPG Excellence [/h1]

Rating: ★★★★★

Star Wars: Knights of the Old Republic (KOTOR) stands as the gold standard of the RPG genre, an exceptional game that flawlessly combines immersive storytelling, memorable characters, and strategic gameplay. With its richly detailed world, engaging narrative, and innovative choice system, KOTOR earns a well-deserved five-star rating.

One of the most remarkable aspects of KOTOR is its captivating storytelling. Set in the Star Wars universe thousands of years before the events of the films, the game weaves a complex and enthralling narrative filled with compelling characters, intriguing mysteries, and moral dilemmas. The player's journey as a Jedi or Sith unfolds through a series of plot twists and personal discoveries, immersing them in a truly epic Star Wars adventure.

The characters in KOTOR are expertly crafted and leave a lasting impression on players. From the enigmatic Jedi Bastila Shan to the enigmatic Sith Lord Darth Malak, each character boasts their own unique backstory, motivations, and complex relationships. The well-written dialogue and exceptional voice acting bring these characters to life, making every interaction a memorable and engaging experience.

The game's choice system is a groundbreaking feature that sets KOTOR apart. Players' decisions throughout the game have significant consequences, shaping the story, alliances, and ultimately determining the path of the main character. This level of player agency adds depth and replayability, encouraging multiple playthroughs to explore the various outcomes and experience the game from different perspectives.

The gameplay mechanics in KOTOR strike a perfect balance between strategy and action. The turn-based combat system, complemented by a robust character customization and skill progression system, offers depth and tactical decision-making. Players can choose from a variety of combat styles and abilities, allowing for personalization and adaptation to different playstyles. The gameplay flows seamlessly with the narrative, creating a cohesive experience that never feels disjointed.

Visually, KOTOR showcases its age, but its art direction and iconic Star Wars design endure. The environments, from the bustling cityscapes of Coruscant to the mysterious forests of Kashyyyk, are richly detailed and evoke a sense of immersion in the Star Wars universe. The sound design, including the iconic musical score, further enhances the atmosphere and nostalgia, transporting players into a galaxy far, far away.

In conclusion, Star Wars: Knights of the Old Republic sets the gold standard for excellence in the RPG genre. Its immersive storytelling, memorable characters, innovative choice system, and strategic gameplay make it an unforgettable gaming experience. With its enduring impact on the genre and the depth of its Star Wars narrative, KOTOR unquestionably deserves a perfect five-star rating. Whether you're a fan of Star Wars or RPGs in general, this game is a must-play and a testament to the power of interactive storytelling.

141476751.review: I highly recommend this game though there are a few caveats to that statement. However, first let me gush. This game is an excellent romp in the Star Wars universe giving a real sense of agency as you navigate dialogue and quests in what may be one of the best executed video game stories ever to be created. I would suggest that playing Star Wars: Knights of the Old Republic feels a bit like playing a Star Wars tabletop RPG with a really great DM. Battle is adequate and, though I'm not a fan of turn-based combat, the queuing system in this game is a big improvement over games that stop all the action while you navigate menus. It was a nice touch to allow a player to pause the game if they need more time to strategize. Leveling and loot are handled well, though I found myself having a hard time finding what item I just picked up in my inventory as it got more and more full throughout the adventure. Music and environments are more than adequate and thrilling at times but the characters are the real stars. With few exceptions, I found the supporting cast to be a joy to interact with. Now, let's be honest, this game is getting long in the tooth and the graphics don't always hold up that well. Animations are pretty clunky and reused models for NPCs can cause some confusion as you begin to question how many identical twins there are in the galaxy. Overall, I do not hold this against the game as it is a product of its time, but new players should be prepared. I opted to play the game with no mods, in a lower resolution and in 4:3 as that felt more authentic to me and the UI scaled better to the game. Even still, with a more than capable PC, I had frequent issues when cutscenes would play. Strange stuttering, long loading, resolution cycling and even crashing occurred. Thankfully, this wasn't something that happened every time and usually only at the outset of major new sections of the game. Probably the most annoying thing I found was that the game's music would cut out while the loading screen to a sub-area was up and it always felt jarring. A nice crossfade of the music would have been so much better. I liked being able to play with the mouse in this game but, for new players, I would probably direct them to something like the Switch's port of this game if possible. Knights of the Old Republic is a fantastic game that deserves to be on a list of must-play video games for every gamer. If you are a fan of Star Wars and great storytelling, give this game a play.

141403213.review:
STAR WARS™ Knights of the Old Republic (KOTOR) is an absolute gem and a must-play for any Star Wars fan or lover of role-playing games. This legendary epic, set thousands of years before the events of the movies, transports players to a rich and immersive universe, delivering an unforgettable experience that continues to stand the test of time.

From the moment you begin your journey as a Jedi or Sith, KOTOR captivates with its engaging story, complex characters, and deep moral choices. The narrative is masterfully crafted, filled with intriguing plot twists, political intrigue, and personal quests. As you uncover the secrets of the Old Republic, your decisions and interactions shape your character’s path, allowing you to embrace the light side or succumb to the temptations of the dark side.

The gameplay in KOTOR strikes a perfect balance between accessible and deep, offering a blend of real-time combat and strategic turn-based elements. The character progression system is robust, allowing you to customize your abilities, skills, and Force powers. The tactical combat encounters, alongside the party management and customization options, ensure that each encounter feels strategic and satisfying.

The world-building in KOTOR is exceptional, capturing the essence of the Star Wars universe with remarkable attention to detail. From iconic locations like Tatooine and Kashyyyk to the diverse range of alien species and starships, every aspect feels meticulously crafted and true to the lore. The music, composed by Jeremy Soule, adds to the immersion, providing a sweeping orchestral score that evokes a sense of awe and familiarity.

One of the standout features of KOTOR is its memorable and well-developed characters. From the witty and charismatic HK-47 to the enigmatic Jedi Bastila Shan, each companion brings a unique perspective and personal story to the adventure. Engaging in meaningful conversations with them deepens your understanding of the Star Wars universe and forges lasting connections.

The game’s modding community has breathed new life into KOTOR, offering a wealth of user-created content that expands upon the already extensive gameplay experience. From new quests and characters to visual enhancements and gameplay tweaks, mods provide even more reasons to revisit and relish in this classic RPG.

While KOTOR’s age may be clear in its graphics and user interface, the storytelling, gameplay, and overall experience make it a true masterpiece that transcends time. Occasional technical issues and minor glitches can occur, but they are overshadowed by the sheer joy of the adventure.

In conclusion, STAR WARS™ Knights of the Old Republic is an unforgettable RPG that immerses players in the Star Wars universe like no other game. Its captivating story, rich characters, and strategic gameplay make it an absolute must-play for fans of the franchise and RPG enthusiasts alike. If you’re ready to embark on an epic journey of light and dark, prepare to be swept away by the timeless magic of KOTOR. May the Force be with you.

140927467.review:
For how outdated the interface is and how the gameplay feels so clunky (turn-based combat played out in real time), I did not expect that Knights of the Old Republic would hook me in for more than a hour really. 

Initially when I bought the game for like 50 pesos, the only kicker for me to buy the game was it was just a cheap Star Wars game. Though I was daunted by the many RPG elements (character creation is one of my weakness when starting a game), I did want to push through the game. I dropped the game eventually because it felt a bit grindy and I wasn't used to the slow pace the game had compared to the more modern action games I've been playing like Hollow Knight or Borderlands 2.

Now with a spark of Star Wars fever, I decided to give it a try. Admittedly, I really just wanted to play Jedi: Fallen Order but KOTOR was all I had for the moment. Getting through the tutorial, I found the combat more and more enduring. I realized that the story had more depth to it once I got used to the old interface and having to playing the game windowed.

After finishing the game two times, both with the light and dark side playthroughs, I can confidently say that KOTOR is one of the finer RPGs in the video game industry. I'd say though that it does not excel in its flexibility in its roleplay. One of which is my standards for quality RPGs but I will say that it makes up for its story pacing and rich lore in the world.

KOTOR's strengths honestly its bite-sized everything. Every encounter for me was exhilarating no matter how small or easy it was. Most encounters last a minute or two while boss battles never go past five (unless you are under-leveled or have a bad build) and I think that's what I find endearing about KOTOR. Compared to other RPGs, KOTOR makes the most out of every battle and makes it short but exciting. You have full control of your character's move set bounded by the turn-based combat of course but you do not have to wait long for their actions as it executes in real time.

The way it presents its plot and its lore isn't them shoving it in your throat or at least that's what I felt like. For all I care, I can just skip dialogue and mow down characters and I would still have fun without the game telling me otherwise. Consequently, I can talk to all the characters and learn more about the world and find advantages from the information I'm getting.

For me, Bioware really made the right choice in choosing an unknown period of the Star Wars canon and making the most out of its worlds and characters. All the planets I've visited were full of life and they always felt like they were there unlike other RPGs. Another point for KOTOR is that I always felt like exploring their environments. And whenever I get bored, the planet usually wraps up everything before I get sick of the planet.

Okay but the plot twist with Revan was so satisfying. I honestly did not see that coming. It didn't feeling forced and I was genuinely shocked and delighted to know that. Maybe it was because I was immersed by the world but props to the plot Bioware made.

Its obvious flaws is the outdated interface and bugs. I think that's just standard for old games but I would really want to see how the remake fares. Though I don't really see why I should revisit the game a third time besides the lightsaber combat (hehe), I think remaking the game would actually make the game perfect and solidify itself as the best RPG I believe.

Another flaw of the game is in its roleplaying. Of course the game has small choices you can make that you can use to roleplay but often, the choices are light side favored. Plot-wise, it heavily implies that you'll always pick the light side which is jarring and the plot feels dysfunctional when you play as a psychopathic dark side character. I would've hoped for a flexible approach in its roleplay as I think there is so much potential in making decisions as a Jedi or Sith.

Overall, I just love Star Wars. Better yet, I love lightsabers and lightsaber battles. I would've wanted to play Fallen Order more but KOTOR has given me a world to get lost in, a riveting and exciting plotline, short but sweet combat, and a lot of bugs. I think KOTOR joins New Vegas as niche games I really like and obsess with once in a while. I would rate KOTOR a 8.5/10. If it had a more satisfying lightsaber combat and more flexibility in its roleplay, I can see it being a perfect 10. Maybe the remake (or remaster?) can fix these problems for me but for now it remains the cult classic everyone knows and loves (and occasionally hate).

140889685.review:
It was pretty good overall, but nothing exceptional. Good enough to be worth a playthrough at the very least.

KOTOR's biggest strength is definitely in its writing. It managed to present a much more interesting and nuanced view of what the Force is and the battle between the Jedi and Sith than any of the actual films ever managed and did so largely through an appropriate means. Each location in the game is exploring these large issues through a somewhat different lens and each has its place to understanding the bigger picture. While I still wouldn't go so far as to say the writing is great, its still much better than most of the other Star Wars related media I've seen.

But on other aspects, the game fares a lot more poorly. Combat is extremely simple and once you've gotten past the introductory area its pretty trivial to get through all of the game's challenges without really needing to think too hard. The way equipment is handled is pretty awful. You will almost never pick up gear that is superior to what you have already, meaning its only real value is to be sold in exchange for better stuff. But the inventory for equipping and selling stuff is atrocious with ever single item confined to a single column you have to scroll through that only shows a small handful of entries at a time. And you have to sell each item individually along with a confirmation prompt every time you sell something even slightly valuable. And even once that's done, whatever equipment you can buy is only marginally better than the gear you have already. Honestly, you just shouldn't engage with the gear system at all unless you're struggling to progress because its not worth the effort otherwise.

And probably the most notable issue is technical performance. While its to be expected of such an old game, its definitely aged poorly in this regard. Lots of loading and stuttering, characters getting stuck in the level geometry, freezing/crashing, and other little bugs here and there are common throughout the experience. Even playing with a patch that's supposed to fix a lot of the issues the game still wasn't in great shape. While it was never bad enough to ruin the experience (Its no Cyberpunk 2077 or anything), it did mean my experience was constantly brought down by a plethora of little things that eroded away at my immersion.

Overall, KOTOR is still a good game. It never reaches the kinds of peaks that elevates it to a masterpiece and its flaws are apparent enough that I couldn't warrant such a title even if it did have fantastic writing. But the things that it does well are still quite good and its flaws aren't terrible. So its probably worth a shot.

140867730.review:
An elegant game from a more civilized age…

This game is jaw-dropping. -Darth Malak

To me Kotor is still cannon. I don’t care what Disney says. What I loved about Kotor was that it really made me FEEL like a Jedi… like I’d earned it.

I love an RPG that embraces roleplaying and makes you FEEL like the character you’re playing. To this day I feel a sense of pride when I replay Kotor. It’s like the complete opposite of how I felt when I watched the Last Jedi. 

Knights of the Old Republic is my single favorite video game of all time. It’s not a good game, it’s a GREAT game. Kotor is one of my all time favorite pieces of Star Wars media. It is my favorite Star Wars thing after the OT. It tells a great story with amazing characters and worlds. The game is a big adventure like the movies where you are the hero and YOU make the choices. 

It’s an RPG so the story is tailored to how you play. I’ve completed this game countless of times and every time I’m discovering new ways to do things, may it be little details or quest outcomes that change because you’ve done (or not) something before. Truly a gem. 

Story is top notch, even to this day. Gameplay is a little clunky, it's a turn based RNG style, and grqphics, even updated are still dated.  It has a high replay-ability, going light side one time, dark another is just the beginning.  Also whether playing for the first time or during a replay make sure you save often and with multiple slots, you never know when you will run into a bug or miss out on a quest. It’s a good way to keep the game’s age from crashing down upon you.

The community is still large which is a HUGE factor for playing older games. i.e. if you have problems there are still lots of people willing to chime in on how to fix it, etc. And there are a large amount of mods that greatly enhance gameplay, including restoring content that was cut from the game before release. It's glorious. I still highly recommend giving it a go, just be prepared to lose hours of your life to it. 

If you’re here… You’ve taken your first step into a larger world. It’s going to be worth it. May the force be with you… always. 

1000/10

140629818.review:
This review is a recommendation based [i]solely[/i] on playing this game on an out-of-the box Steam Deck and not on a desktop PC. I have never been able to make this game work on a desktop PC. 

This game works very well on a Steam Deck. The biggest issue when running on a Steam Deck is that skipping cutscenes tends to cause the game to black screen or get caught on an infinite loading screen. Another major issue is that the game requires a community made control scheme in order to be playable - it has no native controller support as it was released back in the early 2000's. That said, I was able to play through the entire game from start to finish with relative ease!

This is probably the best way to play KOTOR 1 in the modern era, at least on the PC Gaming front. You can play both KOTOR 1 and KOTOR 2 on Steam Deck with very few modifications on the player's end, bar community control inputs. The games are also available on the Switch, where I imagine stability is a tad bit higher than on Steam Deck.

TL;DR (if your attention span is that short): Game works great on Steam Deck, with some minor issues. Game does not work on modern PCs period. Buy it to play on Steam Deck, or do not buy it at all.

140511186.review:
[h1]STAR WARS™ Knights of the Old Republic™[/h1]
STAR WARS™ Knights of the Old Republic™ is an RPG set 4,000 years before the events of New Hope. We play here as a Republic soldier who, along with discovering his force potential, will also discover his own complicated past. I am reviewing this game, after finishing both parts of the KOTOR series, so there may be comparisons. I went through the game in the original version, so I didn't make my life easier by installing mods ( even for resolution ).
[h1]The Plot[/h1]
As this game is almost 20 years old, I will describe that I consider to be important. Starting off, the beginning of the game, and the starting location is a spaceship and a large Ekumenopolis (city-planet). But what I like most about this prologue is that we're not a powerful Jedi or Sith, we're just an ordinary person, so we only use grenades, blasters, and vibroswords. This is a nice change from other Star Wars games. The general idea of the game is that the Republic is at war with the Sith, led by the Dark Lord and a former war hero; Darth Malak, who had previously killed his master; Darth Revan. Or at least that's the Jedi's version of the story. It's an interesting concept because it's more of a civil war than a conflict between empires like in SWTOR, so we can meet old Republic soldiers in the ranks of the Sith. A big part of the game is discovering our potential in the Force, which gives us the opportunity to train on Dantooine to become a Jedi. Even though it's a short segment of the game, I thought it was important because the concept of playing a game where we learn in Jedi academy is very interesting, and personally, I would like to get a game like Hogwarts Legacy, only in the Star Wars universe, which would give us the opportunity to learn at the Jedi and Sith academies. I think such a game would be a great success, and a lot of fun. But getting back to the main thread, it's our job to find maps to the Sith main base, which will take us across the many movie planets and beyond, each with original stories to offer. Probably the most interesting planet is Korriban (the home planet of the Sith) because we have so much opportunities to study at the academy, and funnily enough, we learn so much more philosophy and interesting, ancient history than on Dantooine with the Jedi, and it's just amazing. However, we also have dark and light side mechanics here. Each of our decisions in the dialogues has different consequences, and the world around us will react to them (the corruption of the dark side can even be seen on our face). This has no great consequences, and the decision at the very end of the game, whether we side with the Sith or the Jedi, remains the same. To be honest, the fact that this game allows us to completely go to the dark side, become the Dark Lord of the Sith and murder Jedi makes it the best Star Wars game in terms of story. As for our companions, they're all great, and they add a lot of life to the world/main plot.
[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
Starting from the beginning, i.e. from the character creator. We have some options here, but personally I think they are a bit few. When it comes to appearance, we choose a face from a few already available, and they are not the best, especially since our hero during fights and short comments (because we are mute in dialogues) sounds a bit too young for my taste, and speaking of skill points , powers and attributes, that's enough of them here, although it's a bit hard to experiment here due to the not very balanced system of gaining experience with the class skills already selected for us. We now move on to combat, and it's a very outdated system because it's a turn-based system where we choose a hero and companions and give them orders, then all we do is sit and watch until the fight is over. It also doesn't help that the animations are very meh. Blaster duels are as thrilling as mushroom picking, and vibrosword/lightsaber duels, although they have their own animations, are wooden, sometimes too slow, and the blades often don't even touch each other, so it looks more like a mime duel. Power skills aren't very flashy, but there are a lot of them, so there's some variety here. The maps we are moving through are varied because, as I said, we are moving on many planets here. However, these are quite large maps, divided by zone loading screens, and with the slow movement of the character, walking from one point to another is torture, especially since the game does not have such a thing as markers (only journal entries), so you have to figure everything out by yourself. But apart from that, the locations are really interesting, and the equipment we find in them is not very diverse, but there is enough of it to be satisfied. However, what bothers me in the game are the strange decisions made by the developers. To give examples: on Kashyyk in the Shadowlands there are monkeys that make noise (and they fucking don't stop), the most annoying sound in the history of games, on Tatooine we are molested by desert people who attack us every now and then, in space we move so slowly that in the meantime, I could go and make myself dinner, and in the final location, there are whole swarms of enemies literally thrown at us from the air, and it drags on terribly. It also doesn't help that our character loves to get stuck on every object. And one more thing, but this is a subjective opinion. I know there are a lot of races and languages in Star Wars, but the amount of "languages" that the characters speak is unpleasant, we often see dialogues and cutscenes where aliens growl at each other, groan, etc, and it's really hard to focus on the dialogue, especially that these languages are extremely painful to the ears, even more so when we hear the same thing for the hundredth time, and speaking of repetition, the disadvantage of this game is also the fact that the characters tend to repeat themselves, and explain unnecessary things.
[h1]Technical Matters[/h1]
Like I said, it's an old game. It works on very low resolutions, it broke my save game once, and to be honest, when it comes to graphics and effects, it's bad. For some reason, the game also has graphical bugs and I personally had to turn off the grass to fix it, not to mention that in some locations the game, despite its age, simply runs terribly on higher graphics settings. The music is not typical movie music, but it keeps a high level. The voice actors did a very good job, but I think in some scenes they didn't quite know what they were reading, so the intonation is a bit weird at times.
[h1]Summary[/h1]
An amazing game with the best storyline in the Star Wars universe. It's a classic, and despite the outdated gameplay and technical issues, it's a great product that gives the player a lot of amazing fun. I hope the Remake will keep the high standard (if it ever comes out).

Recommended.
Though you need to go through hoops to make it playable in 1080p. There are many missing content and game-breaking bugs therefore installation of SWKOTOR Restoration 1.2 mod is highly recommended.

[b][u]Keypoints[/u][/b]
3rd person RPG with fixed camera.
Attributes(The good old Strength, Dexterity etc.), Skills(Computers, Lockpicking etc.), Feat trees(Active combat skills and passives), Power trees(Force skills for force using companions)
Dice 20 turn-based combat system that allows you to pause mid-fight and switch between characters, you can queue orders (attacks, skills) during fights.. You can move freely outside of combat.
Open world~ish, different planets and zones, side quests. Each planet have their own unique immersive atmosphere that sucks you in to the game. The tone of the planet is also in line with the story. Consistent.
Other than side quests, there were also swoop(space motorbike) races, duels and card games where you could do some quick buck on certain planets.
Has a compelling story.
Adequate dialogue options. Rich branching, reveals new opportunities for an end-goal.
Balancing Light/Dark side affiliation. This is affected by dialogue options, actions, side quests and other things.
You can have 9 party members in total, aforementioned side affiliation and other choices you make affect the way they act around you and their fate.
There are some interesting puzzles, especially in the ancient temples. *duh*
Musical score by Jeremy Soule.

[b][u]Rant[/u][/b]
However I highly dislike the finale [spoiler] before the boss fight [/spoiler] where you have to run through platforms and there is an endless spawn of enemies, since you can not command, all at once, your party members to disengage from the fight and move towards a position, it becomes highly frustrating navigating through that section, as each newly spawned infinite party sends you back towards where you came from as you are locked out of your party members.

140270091.review:
Just to preface, this is a 2003 game and has TONNES of technical issues getting this to run. Flawless Widescreen is a must for this game imo, I have a 2k monitor and no resolution exists for this game without an external application. I had crashes happening 5 times on occasion when loading into my save just to play the game, and had a few instances of corrupted saves ruining my playthrough. Sometimes you'd just load in and textures would bug out when changing areas and when you try to save (so you can quit and reload), the game crashes and then sets you to 0 hours played. So if you buy this game, make multiple saves and ensure you are updating them throughout and before changing areas. Just make sure the saves you're overwriting aren't your most "current" save because if you save onto that one, it gets corrupted which will waste your time.

Now onto the actual gameplay itself:

Brilliant RPG game, really good story telling as a whole and your companions all have their own neat stories that make them more interesting than in other games I've played, I'm not the kind of person to explore the side quests to do with companions in games because usually they are a waste of time and bloat. But I really enjoyed the side missions here. A lot of the side content in this game is actually pretty good which is something I don't find to be the case in most RPG games, it adds a lot to the feel of the game. The amount of different choices you can make can offer the opportunity for multiple playthroughs if you so wish as you can do a light side playthrough and dark, and they will produce different results at almost all points in the game. The story alone makes this game WELL worth the time to play it.

Gameplay is a weakness of this game however as it is basically turn based D&D combat. There are also quite obviously OP abilities and feats you earn which just make it so when you get in combat you're just spamming the same attack until the enemy is dead which gets stale. Overall though it's a great game and I would recommend to anyone who would like to know more about the republic era and Revan/Malak. If you can deal with dated combat mechanics this game is well worth it, just like Morrowind in that sense if you've played that.

139901741.review:
This is a game from an era when Bioware could do no wrong. Sadly, the stability on modern systems is not guaranteed. A few years ago, it was crashing constantly on my Windows machine right in the beginning hours on Taris, and now it's crashing on Tatooine on my Arch Linux distro. 

Strangely, the game worked perfectly till this point with no crashes (~15 hours of gameplay). Maybe it's a problem only with Tatooine or somehow the fault is with my heavily modded configuration. 

Technical junk aside, the game is still as fun to play as it was many years ago. It doesn't waste your time on dozens of fetch-quests and there is always flexibility when it comes to solutions depending on your available skills. That old-school Bioware charm is still there and with some face-lift modifications (mainly Fens's re-textures of characters, his Mission is especially good) it looks very decent. The game is a must-play for any Star Wars or Bioware fans.

139892358.review:
I've put way more hours into this game than Steam shows because I originally owned the actual discs (yes, physical discs) and later got the Steam version. This is one of the greatest games ever. An immersive storyline, interesting characters, and great gameplay. Despite its 2003 release date, and somewhat dated graphics, I still return to this game every so often to replay it. Because of the branching story and different choices you can make (be evil, be good, kill this guy, steal this item, etc) each playthrough is different. I actually have a difficult time playing as an evil character because the game makes me feel bad about my decisions; very few games can do that! There are also some funny moments, particularly anything that HK-47 says :)

Make sure to get one of the widescreen hacks if you have a modern computer.

Kotor is a great rpg AND amazing star wars game. There's a reason people still talk about it. The progression of events is familiar but the environments you see are different in their own ways. The technology is less advanced, and the conflicts you deal with feel more primitive and more raw in a lot of ways. So on and so forth.

139593506.review:
No es perfecto, pero en general es un muy buen CRPG, especialmente para fans de SW, que merece mucho la pena.

La historia en sí no es ninguna revolución pero sirve para el propósito de avanzar la trama y dejar que los personajes y el mundo reciban la atención que se merecen. Los compañeros están bastante bien implementados, teniendo la mayoría buena cantidad de contenido propio y aportando a la historia. Hay un giro de guión en la segunda mitad del juego que está bastante bien, osea que cuidado con los spoilers.

El combate, si bien a melee tiene animaciones muy buenas, deja que desear para mí. No hay muchas opciones, y las que hay no son especialmente interesantes, incluso incluyendo los poderes de la fuerza. No se hace pesado, pero desde luego no creo que gane mucho en dificultades más altas.

Visualmente se mantiene muy bien en mi opinión, una vez te acostumbras a los gráficos la ambientación está muy lograda y las animaciones faciales aportan mucho.

Por los 3e que me costó es una experiencia muy chula y entretenida, con una historia que merece la pena vivir y personajes entrañables.

139578448.review: If you haven't heard about this game by now, then you're either very young or very new to gaming.  Either way, this is a great beginner game to get into the adventure RPG genre and the story is phenomenal.  If you like Star Wars and you like lore then you're gonna be 110% invested in this story.  Despite the age, the graphics still hold up great, the combat system is fun and pretty customizable, the equipment upgrading is a little sparse but still holds a lot to be discovered and the characters are most definitely memorable.  Also, if you're struggling to get through it, as it does drag a bit in places, just know that the twist ending is well worth the slog this game can be on occasion.

139502364.review:
Not impressed. Immediately crashes after character creation. Game was a good price is supposedly an early ground-breaker series I never played a few years ago. 

I don't appreciate the lack of execution on the introduction to game-play on this platform. 

*Update* 
The game finally worked for me but had to spend a WHOLE weekend trying tips from various KOTOR sources. Mine only worked after disabling menu options and running the game in Admin and previous windows edition. 

Even still probably next most frustrating part of the game is dealing with the inability to walk after engaging in combat. Only fixes seem to be quick saving or loading the game. Simple enough but annoying and tedious. I am clearly not a master of coding but I feel these bugs could easily be fixed by a modest team in a few updates.

The game is very interesting from a casual star wars fan and as a look back to the leap modern games have taken open world concepts the story is interesting and it is the first non-story related game that had real depth and an interesting story. Battle is very basic but that's ok.

If you battle through getting this to work the game is pretty awesome and recommended. Still leaving this as not recommended to purchase until they update the game.

139256295.review: I have never played this game before until now May 2023 and I was born in 2000. I never had a PC, and when I owned an Xbox the "gameplay" never made me want to play it. I recently decided to finally touch this game because I love star wars, and I am mad at my younger self for not playing this back on the Original Xbox! This game is a masterpiece! The story is phenomenal, and the characters are incredible! The gameplay itself is perfect to me, you never had to use your keyboard once (besides the shitty space shooting sections)! It is your typical Si-Fi party based RPG but with the star wars twist! Go ahead and do yourself a favor, buy this game and play it! This game goes on a crazy sale, but even without the steam sales this game is worth the $9.99 price tag! The only negative I can give this game is that you have to mod it to even play it! Be sure to download the community patch, a improved UI mod, and you unfortunately have to mod the game to even get 1080p, but once you mod it the game runs fine. This game is riddled with crazy bugs, many times I would get stuck on a wall, or stuck on my companions with me. But if you can ignore some bugs to experience this amazing game, you will not be disappointed!

138702903.review:
A very good Star Wars game probably the best, being an old game it has unfortunately a lot of technical issue. There is however a lot of guide that you can find on Steam that allow you to correct a lot of bugs and other graphical problems with the help of mods. 

The story of the game is excellent, there is a lot of twist and the plot is intriguing, you have a lot of choices to make and a lot of side quests. You also have a lot of choices in the way you play. You can choose to be aligned with the light side or the dark side which will allow you to have different powers. There is many equipments which will allow you to play the game several times with totally different approaches.

I recommend the game to any rpg fan, especially if you are a star wars fan this one is a must play. The time to finish the game varies depending on how you play, but it's between 15 and 35 hours to beat, which is excellent for its price.

You should play Kotor, and here is why:

For those who likes Mass Effect games (Action RPG, Story Rich and Choices matters)

Kotor is the game for you If you would like to read a lot while playing (very story rich) and also if you appreciate action RPG (actually is turn RPG), the gameplay is easy to learn, furthermore, the choices really matter here, Ligh side path vs Dark side path is there in the whole game and implicates in your chosen path and consequently in the ending. Don't fear the age of this game, because it has an amazing gameplay with an above average storyline. The graphics is not awesome (20 years old game) but isn't bad also, it fulfills the goal and to be realistic it is good for the age. You will need careful with the salve game? Of course you will, because autosave is trouble sometimes, it's similar for games that old. You will need to save the game before heat times, but you get used to. It has minor bugs? Yep, but it's not a big deal. Besides that, I absolutelly recommend to give it a chance. Enjoy the game!

138418844.review:
Playing this game made me realize how you can't trust steam reviews or reviews in general and sometimes it can be a huge echo chamber...like the reviews for this game.

Do you enjoy walking down long winding similar-looking corridors like Halo 1?
Do you enjoy looting every single person you kill?
Do you enjoy slowly looting boxes and lockers constantly while walking down previously mentioned long similar-looking winding corridors?
Do you enjoy trial-and-error gameplay?
Do you enjoy staring at people while they talk for 10 minutes?
Do you enjoy a story that is 30% of the game because everything else are side stories?
Do you enjoy team members standing in your way all the time?
Do you enjoy over exhaustive D&D combat system that requires a ton of research and ultimately have no control over it?
Of the actions you're in control of while in combat, do you like using the same repetitive combat actions?

If so, then this is your game...if not, then I cannot recommend this game to anyone unless you are a D&D fan or an ultra-hardcore Star Wars fan that needs to play all Star Wars games. I fully completed this game because of all the praise. There is a reason why a remake was in the making. Because this game feels like actual work. The only positive things I can think of are the Star Wars aesthetics and multiple ways of playing but is irrelevant because I would never go back and play again. 

If you love this game then that is great. Play your heart out, but this is not the greatest Star Wars game of all time as some people act like it is. It has many flaws that people do not mention. You can tell Bioware slapped a Star Wars environment onto an rpg without thinking about a good gameplay loop beforehand. Even though Jedi Academy is a different type of game and is old with issues as well, it plays surprisingly well today. Not Kotor. This game needs a complete overhaul for a remake. 4/10

138314066.review:
One of the best Star Wars games ever released in terms of story.

Easily my favourite twist in a video game, no spoilers in this review but trust me, the reveal is worth every minute of build up.

My biggest gripe with the game is the final quarter however, and if you're thinking of playing this game you should know this. Once you have explored the main planets in your quest you are sent to the final area to confront the final boss. This area is unbelievably cheap with it's combat focus, with infinitely respawning enemies and a corridor dash filled with some of the toughest opponents in the game that constantly spam grenades. This isn't even mentioning the final boss which is a 30 minute endurance test if you haven't invested experience points correctly. I wouldn't be so annoyed with this decision but it kind of makes characters builds that focus on speech or force powers completely useless as you will have virtually no chance of beating the game fairly unless you spec into a tough Jedi/Sith Warrior. 

On my first playthrough I tried to make a smooth talking mercenary ala Han Solo, but this is completely nonviable as soon as you reach this final section of the game. This sucks as there's nothing worse than spending 30 odd hours in a playthrough only to find out it was all pointless because the final boss is immune to virtually all force attacks and no way to beat him other than direct confrontation. 

Something to note if you're just starting off with this game, I wish someone told me this before I invested so much time for nothing. Still more than worth playing though, maybe just quit right before this really annoying and drawn out ending.

138241697.review:
[b]Modding is required to run this on a modern setup but it isn't too difficult if you take the time to read through the steps of a community guide to help avoid any compatibility issues and bugs[/b]

I've seen a few people say that KOTOR doesn't hold up anymore and it's purely nostalgic however after giving this game a chance for the first time, I honestly disagree.

-The many characters that come with different dialogue options and the ability to choose between light/dark side paths makes this old game really fun and immersive. So much so that it's comparable to the quality of SWTOR even though this is about a decade older? 

-The exploration of the main story, star wars lore, and various planets stays fun in between cutscenes and conversations because of the roll-based combat built around classes, gear, stats, and abilities. 

-Obviously graphics are seriously outdated but honestly if that's whats preventing you from playing this game then this isn't for you.

137768346.review:
Your father's favourite Star Wars title. This is the game of a true Star Wars fan. Not as clumsy or random as an EA title; an elegant game for a more civilised age. 

For over 30 years, LucasArts were the guardians of quality and integrity in the Star Wars universe. Before the dark times... before Disney. 


What rarity it is to have such an immersive experience - this game is simply a masterpiece in design and story-telling. I've not played this game on Steam in any meaningful way, but 20 years ago I played this game from start to finish and it has stayed with me ever since. I don't know of a single game that ever affected me so deeply or profoundly as this one. The characters and story were exceptionally well written and compelling, and all of it taking place in a universe I cherished and loved. 

I weep over the fall of Star Wars - from the grand and lofty heights that this title represented, to the brutalised corpse of an IP that now lay before us.

Enjoy this game, and remember a better time that was Star Wars.

Yes the gameplay.... ooh the gameplay. It comes from that awkward time before devs really knew how to transition from tabletop to videogame and it suffers greatly because of it. There are multiple moments where you'll tear your hair out, desperately trying to leave this open area full of goons. Despite this, force yourself to slog through those multiple frustrating combat zones and you'll find yourself with one of the best Star Wars tales ever told, not just the overarching story but the many sidequests.

137428623.review:
I originally played this on the Xbox, and it remains my favorite Star Wars game of all time. I've sunk hundreds of hours into this game, although few of them have been here on Steam.

KoTOR is an RPG in the truest sense, with several phenomenally unique worlds, cultures, and characters. It plays a lot like Dragon Age Origins, though obviously sci-fi instead of high fantasy, in that you build a character from a class, select the attributes and skills you want to build and use, and your actions and game play choices have actual impacts on the plot lines and characters. There are many sequences you'll never see unless you take enough Light or Dark side actions, which gives the game plenty of replay value. If you want to be so good that Sith characters will turn to the light and forsake the Dark side, and you become a paragon of light and goodness, taking down evil big corp and the Sith menace? Go for it! If you want to be so evil your allies turn on each other, flee from you in terror, or try to kill you as you seize power? Have at! If you just want to see the plot through and lean a bit in whatever way suits your fancy from situation to situation? You're free to do so! It's all up to you and what moral choices you want to make, assuming you have the skills (or resources) to back up your actions.

In addition to all that, the writing is amazing, witty, and memorable, with some of the coolest and/or funniest quotes I've encountered in games. Each world has an ultimate goal you need to complete, but how you get there and what bridges you build or burn is entirely up to you. Your party can be diversified in whatever way you like to support your favored play style and/or with your moral alignments. Additionally, every party member has a story you can dig into and resolve, often across multiple worlds, but you aren't forced to interact with them beyond the main plot if you don't want to.

This game is a gem! The core mechanics are pretty D&D but allow beginners an easy start. Combat animations were top-notch at the time and still look cool today. The design is somewhat questionable in certain areas but overall it fits well with the universe. Players get to experience a couple of known planets and some new ones. Each planet has its own neat plot and somehow I keep coming back to this game every year or two just to relive the glory. Sound is good, as are the voice actors, atleast for the most part. Like every early BioWare game, bonding with your companions and learning of their past is essential to the experience. As IGN would say: This game makes you FEEL like a jedi.

Summary: If you never played this one, do it now! I guarantee you will not regret it. Oh, and before I forget, a message to people disagreeing: You are nitpicking and biased, I win, bye bye!

137293149.review:
They don't make 'em like they used to. I was into SW for a brief period when the first two LEGO games came out, but didn't get back into it recently, when my best friend got me an assortment of the games. He had been trying to sell me on it for years and it was up my alley, but I didn't end up playing it until the stars aligned in the right order.

The movement and combat are off-putting when playing nowadays, but if you play a lot of 90's point-and-click adventures a lot, it's a natural progression from those and would feel at home. The selection of Force Powers and abilities are fun and fair for any type of playthrough. The things I would say make the game are the Light/Dark system and the story in general. This is peak Star Wars when it comes to storytelling and the nature of its universe.

The story of this game and the relationships between your player character and their companions helped me through a time where I was fighting a lot of Light vs Dark actions in my own life and a rogue lover who saved me before turning and finally coming back together in a cathartic end. Liea/Han and Padme/Anakin have nothing on the romance in this game and the characters/relationships in general are so much deeper than anything else in SW, even inspiring Bioware to make its own outstandingly successful IP, Mass Effect.

There is an outstanding sequel with its own set of philosophy about the grey zones of good and evil, which was left on a cliffhanger as a planned trilogy, but they both rely heavily on the story and events of this first game. I'm glad I finally got to play this masterpiece and it has truly changed my life. I can't stop playing or coming back to either of these games since starting to play them.
