137287637.review:
Not much to review in a 20 year old game. We all know what KOTOR is. What I will comment on is the stability of the port to PC. It's shaky at best. One constant issue is my characters stop responding to movement commands. WASD stops working for one or more characters forcing me to swap to one that is working. In solo sequences I am forced to re-load the game file to move again. It happens most often after combat, as if the game can't handle the transition back from an encounter. 
Whenever there is a vision sequence between planets the entire client closes as if the game crashed, leaving me on my desktop, but the game is simply minimized for some reason. 
Audio and clipping issues are less common, although it has happened where characters have clipped beyond the room they were meant to be. 
Overall it is a serviceable port but will take a bit of work-around for the clunky bits.

137165187.review:
Many people say that this is the best Star wars game to date, and I kind of have to agree. Granted I actually knew the main twist beforehand, the story was still intriguing. The characters are well thought out (granted with a next gen polish they could be even further), and for its age, the gameplay is not that bad either (granted in a few areas it is completely unbalanced).
It is one of those games that completely deserve a remake of the same quality as Resident evil 2, Resident Evil 4 and Dead Space has gotten. One that respects the original, and improves upon it wherever it is necessary.
I do believe that by incorporating a combat system like the one in Jedi: Fallen order (granted I do not really know how the team mechanic could be kept in), starship combat as the one in Star Wars Battle front 2, and updated graphics, reworked VA, and dialogue it could claim the title of the best Star Wars game of this generation as well.
I hope Aspyr does a good job with the remakes.
It was nice to see what the origins of Bioware were, before jumping into the spotlight with Mass Effect and Dragon Age. A time where their games were still made with passion.

136720647.review:
"If you are tired of Disney’s shitty canon story and shitty privileged main characters, you should play this game as a Star Wars lover."

STAR WARS™ Knights of the Old Republic is a role-playing game that lets you create your own character and choose your alignment in the Star Wars universe. You can explore eight different planets, interact with various characters and factions, and learn to use the Force and wield a lightsaber. The game has a rich story with multiple endings, depending on your choices and actions.

Pros:
- lot of replay value, as you can try different builds, companions, quests, and outcomes.
- deep and immersive lore, with references to the movies and other Star Wars media.
- memorable soundtrack and voice acting, with iconic themes and characters.
- variety of gameplay options, such as stealth, combat, hacking, persuasion, and minigames.

Cons:
- quite old and may not run well on modern systems or devices.
- game has some bugs and glitches that may affect your experience or progress.
- outdated graphics and animations that may look dated or clunky.
- balance issues and exploits that may make it too easy or too hard.

 Overall, I would recommend this game to any Star Wars fan or RPG lover who wants to experience a classic and influential game in the genre. It is one of the best Star Wars games ever made and deserves a place in your library. 8.5/10

136585954.review:
I think, none of the other BioWare games had the impact on gaming as Star Wars: Knights of the Old Republic had. Originally released in 2003 on Xbox, it was the culmination of everything the company did up until that point, but streamlined (in the best possible way) for consoles and due to that (and the Star Wars setting) it managed to cover an audience so huge no “western” RPG covered before. It kickstarted the rise in popularity of morality systems, romance options, “home bases” with companions to choose from… All of it existed in games before, but KotOR became a template for lots of games to follow. All while also being, arguably, the least controversial and most beloved Star Wars product from the whole prequel period of the franchise.

I played this game a lot back in the day, but after the sequel (which I loved so much more), I revisited it less and less and the last time I’ve played it was more than 15 years ago. Now that the game is turning 20, I’ve decided to finally revisit it and see how it fares.

BioWare made a very smart choice when creating the game in an established universe – they chose a time period where they had full freedom of writing. So, KotOR takes place 4 thousand years before the movies and is thus free of all the story and character baggage that would’ve implied. Which even in 2001 when the game was first announced was a lot. And now after the stupidly crazy amount of products Disney churned out, all dancing around the original trilogy (including the sequel trilogy), the story of the game feels especially fresh. Lots of the familiar concepts and ideas are here. Some things are just being established, some are only hinted upon and a lot of the ideas are new or at least were new for the time. For how dreaded the prequel period of the franchise seems to be with lots of people, the lore building it inspired in talented writers led to a world that was far more exciting and interesting than the constant circling around the Skywalkers that used to happen before that.

The core of the story and its big twist, are still excellent. They might no longer surprise people in this day and age, but BioWare crafted a really good adventure for its time and, also being smart about it, only ever attempted to repeat a twist of this kind with Jade Empire (their next project). A lot of the writing is wonderful, the planets you get to visit along your path to save the galaxy from the Sith led by Darth Malak are varied. BioWare continued with their usage of “The Four Map Pieces” structure from Neverwinter Nights, except this time it was literally four map pieces, just like in Monkey Island 2. Visually the game was impressive and even today it looks very good, though, sadly, it does not natively support high resolutions or widescreen ratios. And the music is fittingly “very Star Wars” in the best way. So much of the experience of the title remains impressive and wonderful even 20 years later.

Yet, so much of it aged so poorly or haven’t been great in the first place. The companions, for one, are among the least memorable characters in the whole BioWare history. People tend to love HK-47 for a reason – he’s possibly most amusing character in the whole game. The rest of the crew ranges from “oh, I forgot you’re here” to “oh no, I have to talk to Carth and Bastilla again…” All characters (except for T3-M4) have optional dialogues and even side stories you can do, but some are there seemingly just to exist and some end before you can blink an eye and the character has zero impact on the rest of the story. It’s weird to think that even in NWN1 or BG1 characters had more personality and charm, even though in the first they were used more as tools and in the second almost all of them were skippable and killable.

Another thing that has been a problem since the day the game got released, is the way pathfinding and action queue constantly breaks. You and your companions, despite being directly controllable (which was an option in NWN1), constantly get stuck on nothing or queue up actions in a bizarre order or ignore things they shouldn’t ignore. Except now, 20 years later, I’ve experienced the game breaking even more spectacularly. Cutscene triggers teleporting me into other locations, items duplicating inside my inventory to ridiculous numbers, cutscenes that refuse to start or fade the screen to black and never unfade it… Game can also crash while saving corrupting your save file or crash at some other random spot. The game used to be frustrating, but now the problems only multiplied.

Although, even if all issues were to be fixed and the title would work as designed without issue, you’d get extended sections of genuinely boring gameplay. For how cool in ideas and stories some planets are, the level and encounter design is horrible. The entirety of the last act in the game is at times insufferable with how much combat there is and how boring it gets at the character levels you’re at. Given that BioWare essentially adapted a simplified version of D&D rules (from their previous BG and NWN experience) into Star Wars universe, it means that sometimes you’re just watching characters dance around missing each other because invisible dice just rolled that way, and sometimes you critical hit your opposition into oblivion before the fight even starts.

Still, there’s a lot of great stuff about the original Star Wars: Knights of the Old Republic that BioWare would continuously revisit in their later games… Which is also damning to this title. Original Mass Effect trilogy, for example, repeated basically every single aspect worth repeating across the games with new twists, turns and often better gameplay and more nuanced stories. All the character traits from this game were revisited, but improved in every way, in future titles. With only Light/Dark vs Paragon/Renegade being handled better in KotOR (as Mass Effect motivates you to grind those points). Though at the same time, it’s not like they didn’t revisit this idea with a twist in Jade Empire as well. And the non-linear choice-driven main character personality shaping gameplay was done far far better in the first two Dragon Age titles. BioWare cannibalised KotOR so much, it almost loses relevance…

But I still think there’s an audience for this game. Star Wars: Knights of the Old Republic still has plenty of cool ideas and elements worth experiencing. As long as you can solve the technical issues with the game. Would I revisit this game again in the future? Probably no. But I’ve already played it many times before. If you haven’t – it’s still a game worth checking out. And if nothing else, it’s still a game worth remembering.

136567889.review: Peak fiction. KOTOR is incredibly ahead of its time, so much so that It doesn't feel boring or that clunky even to this date. A must play for Star Wars and RPG fans alike.

136566840.review:
Classic game from the heydays of Bioware magic. This game gave rise to an entire alternate generation of Star Wars stories and it started out strong. If you played it back in the day, it's only better. If you never did... well it might be painful. The screenshots may show action but this is actually a slow-plod through a world filled with mostly dialogue and a very clunky combat system.

If you like reading and listening to... just so, so, so much dialogue.. than this game is great, but I understand that's a niche audience.

You can also check the KOTOR reddit for a mod-combatability list that will turn this game into a pretty respectable 4k, widescreen upgrade with almost all the errors fixed and some sizeable upgrades to the gameplay. That said it took me no less than 4 hours to get all those mods installed (and I don't think you could safely do it much quicker). It sure is purdy though.

136382724.review: An absolute must-play for any Star Wars fan, especially those who either haven't dabbled in the Old Republic era of Star Wars, or who have played the MMO and want to know the events that led up to it. Although some people might find the combat system to be a little dated, I feel like there's something to be said for the slower pacing in this game, and the story and world-building and incredibly charming, memorable, and, most importantly, unintentionally comical. A lot of nuances are lost when it comes to making moral-based decisions in this game, and instead of the occasionally morally grey ambiguity of the choices you can make in the sequel, which I also highly recommend playing, your character in this game is either a bastion of righteousness or a completely unhinged sociopath- I highly recommend playing the game more than once, which I would say takes roughly 16-20 hours, depending on how many side quests you do, to see where each path leads you!

This game is very very fun, especially if you're a star wars lore fan. The story line in engaging and if you're a fan of SWTOR the two games have connected lore. As the game progresses I think it gets more and more fun. Of course, this is a 20+ year old game so do not expect awesome graphics or riveting game play. 

if you are playing this game on anything besides a Windows computer from 2005 it will be a bitch to get started and running. Formatting issues, running issues, random crashes: the game is very finicky and I recommend a) saving your progress very very often and b) if you find a setting that works with you, don't fuck with it. 
On my Windows 11 computer I have to use Flawless Widescreen for the game to be playable and because it is my first time using it it took me about 3 hours to figure it out. Unless you are familiar with playing older games on newer computers, it will take a bit of wrestling with the game in order for it to run properly, not only on first startup but every startup after that. 

TL;DR - I recommend the game for the game itself, but just getting it to run on a newer computer is a massive, massive headache.  Luckily, there is a guide by DarK_St3alth that is very very helpful for getting the game up and running.

133910987.review:
Here are several reasons to play STAR WARS - Knights of the Old Republic:

Lightsabers, duh! Who doesn't love wielding a glowing sword made of pure energy? It's like a laser pointer on steroids.

You get to make important decisions that affect the story, like whether to save someone's life or throw them into a pit of rancors. The power is in your hands (or your mouse clicks, really).

The force is strong with this one. You can use your Jedi mind tricks to convince NPCs to do your bidding. Who needs persuasion when you have the power of the force?

You get to explore the galaxy and visit iconic planets like Tatooine and Kashyyyk. Just watch out for any sand people or giant spiders, they can be a bit... territorial.

The game has memorable characters like HK-47, the sassy assassin droid who wants to kill all organic life, and Carth Onasi, the lovable Republic soldier who always has a bone to pick with somebody.

You can choose to be a light side or dark side character, and your choices affect your alignment and gameplay. So whether you want to be a benevolent Jedi or a ruthless Sith, the choice is yours.

The game has a great story that will keep you engaged and invested from beginning to end. It's like watching a Star Wars movie, except you get to be the hero (or villain) yourself.

The game is a classic RPG that combines the best elements of turn-based and real-time combat. So whether you like strategy or action, there's something for everyone.

May the force be with you on your gaming journey!

133832190.review:
Star Wars: Knights of the Old Republic is a gaming classic for a reason. With that said, it's not perfect and it shows its age in several ways. Even though the game ran fine for me, I encountered enough bugs to feel encouraged to get a [url=https://deadlystream.com/files/file/1258-kotor-1-community-patch/]community patch mod[/url]. Even after I installed the mod an encounter that had its own cutscene and everything didn't spawn in. Old game is old, basically, something that is worth keeping in mind.

And yet, the minor issues I had pales compared to what the game has to offer. I played it for the first time this year, so I can say that it wasn't just great for its time, it is great period. It's not an unusual sentiment, but I'll try to unpack some of why that is – together with some obstacles along the way.

To start off, this game is very, very Star Wars. As in, the game makes an effort to include as many aspects of Star Wars as possible. There is the normal fair of Jedi, Sith and various bounty hunters and freedom fighters, but there is also pod racing, turret space combat, gambling in form of a card game and even galactical politics. The planets are also reminiscent of what we see in the movies, sometimes featuring the same ones (like Kashyyyk or Tatooine) or ones with a similar theme (a city planet, an ocean planet). There are familiar scenarios as well, like escaping an enemy ship after being captured. Basically, if you've seen it in the movies (the first six, anyway), there is a good chance that you'll see it in this game.

This could have felt derivative and cynical, but it's expanded upon and spun in enough of a different direction that it ends up being referential instead. Every aspect is well thought out within the limitations that the game is working with and, more importantly, you can feel the enthusiasm that went into each element of the game. Pod racing is not just a cutscene or something that happens in the background, it has a fully fleshed-out minigame attached to it. Combat has extra animations where fighters lock swords, each planet have their own culture and politics that influence quests, encounter design takes into account where you are and who is attacking, if they're even battles at all. There are options for diplomacy or brute force throughout the game, which again takes into account who you are talking to and why. Everything in this game feels hand crafted, basically, and I really appreciated that when I played.

So, how does it play then? Well, that's where we return to the age thing. Don't get me wrong, the game plays pretty well. You select an enemy to attack them, then you have a number of special attacks and abilities that you use on top of that. The UI is quite clear once you get used to it, enemies are fair and there is some variety in the combat scenarios, even if the main gameplay loop can get repetitive. However... I could never quite shake the feeling that KotOR's systems are just an infancy version of Dragon Age: Origins. Which is exactly what it is, of course; this game was the progenitor to a lot that DA:O mastered. The party AI behaviours, the real-time-with-pause, the spell queueing and focus on crowd control – they're all there, but simpler, less developed. Is that a fair criticism? No, but yet it matters for a modern audience that has access to both games. Not something to blame it for, just a reality of getting old.

What I can blame the game for is the controls. Again, it's an old game, but you get stuck on [i]everything[/i] in this game. You get stuck on random debris, you get stuck on doors, you get stuck in corners. Most of all you get stuck on your party members, who seem to enjoy seeing you try to squirm and squeeze your way past them while they stand around like statues, given that they trap you as soon as they get the chance. And the targeting is far from great either. Clicking the right character in combat can be quite frustrating when everyone is close to each other, which isn't helped by the fact that your character can decide to start attacking a different target as soon as you're not directly controlling them. Looting is also a chore, since half the time the targeting system gets waylaid by one of your party members stepping on a corpse, leading to you having to run around in a big circle to reset it. This also applies to containers that are too close together, or active grenades overlapping with items on the floor. It never ceased to annoy me throughout the whole game.

With that out of the way, let's end with a positive. It's a big one: the story. Nothing in KotOR ever falls below good in the writing department, with good characters, great main and side quests, fantastic world building and amazing story structure. The dialogue is maybe where you can criticise the game a bit, it's built around a Light vs Dark narrative which shows in the dialogue options. Where this game really shines however is in its set up and pay off, which is among if not the best I've ever seen in a game. The game's first half is extremely good in hindsight, something you will probably end up reflecting on before the end, and the rest is pretty great as well. 

If you enjoy storytelling in games, then this alone is a reason to experience KotOR, in whatever form you deem fit. The fact that there's also a very good game attached, well, that's quite the bonus on top.

133830866.review:
Star Wars Knights of the Old Republic is a masterpiece of modern video game storytelling. From the moment you begin your journey in the vast, sprawling galaxy of the Star Wars universe, you are completely immersed in a world that is both familiar and completely fresh. The game is a triumph of character development, world-building, and narrative structure, blending together a host of elements from the Star Wars universe to create something truly remarkable.

At its core, Knights of the Old Republic is a role-playing game that allows you to create your own character and explore the galaxy in whatever way you see fit. The game is filled with interesting and complex characters, each with their own motivations and backstories. From the charming rogue Han Solo-esque smuggler to the wise and powerful Jedi Master, the cast of characters is diverse and engaging.

The world-building in Knights of the Old Republic is simply astounding. From the bustling cities to the desolate wastelands, every location in the game is meticulously crafted and filled with detail. The architecture, the landscapes, and the characters themselves are all inspired by the rich tapestry of the Star Wars universe, and the game does an excellent job of capturing the feel and atmosphere of the films.

The game's narrative structure is also a standout feature. The story is both epic and intimate, with a host of twists and turns that will keep you on the edge of your seat throughout. The game's main questline is engaging and well-paced, but the real strength of Knights of the Old Republic lies in its many side quests and optional content. Each quest feels like a unique and compelling story in its own right, and the game rewards you for exploring its vast world and engaging with its characters.

In terms of gameplay, Knights of the Old Republic is a classic role-playing game with deep systems for character customization and combat. The game's turn-based combat is engaging and strategic, with a host of abilities and tactics to master. Whether you prefer to engage in combat with a lightsaber or a blaster, the game gives you plenty of options to play the way you want.

Overall, Star Wars Knights of the Old Republic is an incredible achievement in video game storytelling. It's a game that can be enjoyed by both die-hard Star Wars fans and newcomers to the series alike. With its engrossing world-building, memorable characters, and engaging gameplay, Knights of the Old Republic is a classic that has stood the test of time and continues to be a beloved favorite of gamers around the world.

This isn't a... normal review of KOTOR [that one's easy, it's a masterpiece DND adaptation of Star Wars]

This a review of an in-progress CO-OP run of KOTOR via 'backseat gaming' (hotseat, really). While it's awkward to move different characters, and prone to whatever you use  to share screens being wonky, playing it with an handful of friends really breaths fresh air into the game. Whether voting on decisions, or playing combat like an actual TTRPG, it's actually really fun, not a style for everyone though.

2-3 people is ideal, but if you've played a ton and don't mind sitting out or just being the guy with the controller, 4 is workable

maybe make some character sheets or just a breakdown of what each character is good at, discord screen share is a pretty decent option if you have a good connection and aren't using hardware acceleration.

133363223.review:
Antes que nada, tengamos unos puntos en consideración:

1) Envejeció muy mal (gráfica y jugablemente).
2) La historia es lo que sostiene el juego.
3) Su sistema de combate es solido.

Considerando lo anterior, el juego se merece un INDISPENSABLE.

Es un juego muy bueno al cual los años le pasaron factura. La historia se mantiene muy bien, pero el combate y los gráficos se sienten DEMASIADO viejos, la progresión de los personajes es muy buena pero algo difícil de entender en tu primera run o sin una guía.
Me decidí a volverlo a jugar hoy en día por el anuncio de su REMAKE, con la nostalgia como bandera me di cuenta de que el juego tiene muchos fallos (considerando los juegos actuales). Mapas vacíos, combates injustos y mas, pero al finalizar la aventura sentí mucha felicidad y nostalgia.

Espero que lo puedan probar tanto al original como al remake (cuando salga XD)

KOTOR, despite perhaps being a little bit overrated and with god awful combat, is still worth playing, because despite its flaws, it is still one of the masterpiece RPGs. While dealing with the combat tends to be annoying and frustrating, and some of the other gameplay mechanics were already dated on its release, it still offers a large variety of high quality content, both in terms of the RPG mechanics themselves, but also quests, characters and a pretty good main and side narrative set.

So why am I not recommending it? Simply put, the Steam version is broken. It took several different driver versions, multiple changes to settings, etc. until I got the game to run past the prologue mission, and even then, the game continues to crash, freeze, randomly change resolution during some cutscenes, etc. It's a mess and should not be sold as it is currently, because it can hardly be considered a functioning product.

If you want to play KOTOR and you only have a PC, just get the original Xbox version and run it on an emulator, it will actually work properly that way...

This game is...fine. Look I'm a huge star war nerd, but as someone who played this game nearly 20 years after its initial release, I don't really get the hype. Maybe its because I've known about Revan as long as I've known about Kotor, but the story felt like a just a rehash of other star wars media with not much added. Also most of these Bioware games are built on how much you care about the companions and unfortunately for me I kinda cared about two and was bored or annoyed by the rest. Sorry Jennifer Hale, I love you but even you can't make me care about Bastila. 

Altogether I don't think that this is a horrible game, but it is outdated in both game-play and story-wise and might be disappointing to new more modern players who are playing this game for the first time. If you're a new Star Wars fan going through old Legends material, you totally should give this game a shot, but don't let the hype get to you and be prepared for some slow frustrating combat and voice acting from 2003.

132575425.review:
[h1]Brief Review of Knights of the Old Republic[/h1]

[i]“It is four thousand years before the Galactic Empire and hundreds of Jedi Knights have fallen in battle against the ruthlessness of… The Walt Disney Company.”[/i] *cue Imperial March music*

Oops, I may not have the gotten the above byline quite right. That was probably offsides. Let’s carry on with the game assessment…

[i]This review is dedicated to the 104 employees who gave their lives in service to Systech Corporation.[/i]

Having played through Knights of the Old Republic on multiple platforms, I can confidently say that it is one of my favorite games of all time. There is an old strategy guide on my shelf that I purchased when the game first released back in the day. I broke it out for my latest playthrough that just ended on February 10, 2023.

What can I say? I love the setting, the characterizations, voice acting, galactic conflict, and universal themes—not to mention the lightsabers and Wookies, man. When I first played the game, I was blindsided by the plot twist that is all too well known now. I did not see it coming.

And yet, this review would be remiss without mentioning the things that plague my playthroughs; that is, the galling space battles and laborious swoop racing. Your mileage may vary, but I truly despise those mini-games. Pazaak is fun nevertheless 😊

Kotor is entertaining. I just have a grand time playing. I find it fun visiting the planets, engaging in quests, and fighting for a better (or worse) tomorrow for the Republic. If you want to give it a go, there are some very talented mod makers who create quality of life, gameplay, and graphic upgrades.

For me, this is how a Star Wars game should be made.

132523215.review:
One of the most fantastic licenses in the world, plot developments that made my jaw drop, and plenty of potential to build your own character through moral choices and combat builds. But it’s the characters that make Knights of the Old Republic – for all of its wild wonders, it understands people.

Clearly the game is to be lauded for more than this – it’s the game that did Star Wars better than George Lucas himself, let alone Disney – but it speaks of what made the game so special. Its characters, like Mission, or HK-47 (who is rightly lauded as the best NPC of all time), are still so amazingly real and enthralling today, and it’s what I remember most fondly from the Old Republic.

132288664.review:
[h1] TL:DR: Star Wars D&D. Do you love a good story with satisfying gameplay although it is starting to show its age? Then look no further than Star Wars: Knights of the Old Republic! 9.5/10 [/h1]
Wow, just what an adventure. If you're a fan of star wars and D&D, chances are you will enjoy this game. It has some issues that show its age, but if you give it a chance, you will be in for a treat. 
[h1] First, the bad [/h1]
The pathfinding. Oh dear lord, the pathfinding. Much of the difficulty comes from ordering a command and watching the ai struggle to find a route to the enemy. At which point you just manually control and move them to the position yourselves. Another annoying feature comes mostly to force characters. Whenever the ai retargets to a new enemy it resets all the commands on the bar for me. Unsure if this is normal, but it was annoying when my force characters would constantly spend points haphazardly when I needed them the most. These two issues are the only thing imo that is holding back this game. Minor inconveniences most of which can be solved if you enable the pause after every combat round feature in the options menu.
[h1] Now the good [/h1]
Everything else. From the story down to the numbers of a blaster this game does it all very well. The combat is so D&D and I'm here for it. If you have played that classic tabletop adventure game then stepping into KOTOR will feel natural to you. The story is just *chef's kiss*. It poses a good ethical or moral quandary to the Jedi and the force that will make even seasoned star wars vets pause the game and go, "You know, it's got a point". If you're not in it for the massive thought bomb the game won't hesitate to drop, then you can follow a really simple plot that leads to a satisfying twist. If you ever played Bioshock, think about that in terms of gratification. "Would you kindly?"
Awesome side quest design. They are simple but effective. Multiple different ways to approach them. It gives you a way to conquer each quest in a manner that feels wholly your own. I always applaud simple but effective quest design. There are a ton to choose from and all are a treat, don't skip out on them if you can.
The first stop on my journey to experience classic RPG's that I missed out on and boy what a treat. Looking forward to KOTOR 2!

132088830.review:
OOOOK I need to get this out now because I have some things to say about this game that stop me from saying "10/10 HIGHLY RECOMMEND!" because I like it in places and I want to beat the shit out of my laptop rip my hair out light my laptop on fire take a piss on it bury it in my back garden and dance on it's grave and take a shit on the previously mentioned grave.

STORY: No spoilers but the story is amazing and it's the only reason I kept playing, if the character interactions and the story-line were just OK I would have begged steam for my money back, you may favour some characters and their stories more than I did but that's neither here nor there. My favourite characters were Carth Onasi and Bastila Shan the two most important characters in the game so I lucked out but Jolee Bindo is a close third. The protagonist surprisingly has a bit of depth and isn't just some rando there's something more to them that even they aren't aware of. The ending or at least the good ending kind of falls flat to me, you don't get to say goodbye to the characters you've grown to really like you just get talked to by two characters that you probably wont give a fuck about I wanted to say something or hear a few words from them at least or an epilogue for you to play through.

GAMEPLAY: The idea of taking a turn based rpg format into a 3d space sounds like a good idea on paper but in practice it is the most frustrating thing about this game. Occasionally when you run away to heal yourself your character will stop in place to wait for the enemy to hit you and if you are underleveled you are going to be dying a LOT and it really pissed me off when the dark jedi started coming in with moves that choke you it's an iconic skill don't get me wrong but it's fucking annoying to deal with. The skills are pretty neat you can upgrade your mind trick but if you funnel all your skill points into persuade then you'll be using mind trick like when everything fails. The movement can be pretty janky it relies on tank controls which may or may not be a bad thing to you but I got used to it pretty quick so you should to.

GRAPHICS: The ps2 era graphics look pretty good to me I like it a lot, it's not mind blowing but it gets the job done word of advice though, the graphics for grass can go absolutely nuts sometimes and can make the experience almost unbearable so turn that shit off the moment you get a chance you wont miss it at all.

GLITCHES: First off random invisible walls that will stop you in your place one moment  but when you turn and go back you can walk through just fine there's the aforementioned grass glitching to high heaven, and then there's the VERY irritating glitch where the dialogue will just skip right to the end this isn't an option in game it just does this randomly, and I'm counting my lucky stars that that didn't happen during an important character moment.

Overall if you can swallow the god awful battle system then you're in paradise overall a 7/10

132041722.review:
It was ok.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]

The gameplay is pretty standard RPG stuff, it uses a sort of pause-and-play style for the combat. The combat itself isn’t very engaging, it kind of just revolves around clicking the move you want and waiting. There is some diversity in what you can do but it is mostly either ranged or close attacks with a few stuns and such, each fight is pretty much the same with difficulty decided by the standard d20 system. For the most part, combat is pretty minimal and as such is pretty bearable, it does ramp up immensely towards the very end of the game becoming a slog and not very enjoyable. Aside from combat, there are two other minigames those being a card game that I never played and a racing one that I played once for the story requirements. Most of the rest of the gameplay is walking around and talking with others, luckily this aspect is very good. There are a number of companions that can be recruited some of which fill different archetypes to fill out the party, each of them are interesting though. There are several different planets that are visited throughout the game each with unique environments, some are better and more full than others and with interesting quests that enhance the story, while others are more lackluster. The stories with minimal combat are the best ones as the stories and characters become centerpieces. The length of the planets is very varied with the first one being much longer than the others and aside from the very last area is the least interesting of them. There is no traditional alignment system but there is a simple light and dark system, light of course being good and dark being bad, not too complex but it does fit with the Star Wars universe. The game features a class system that works pretty well, however pretty far into the game the character will switch classes and get a whole new set of abilities and useful stats which makes the first few levels not as effective, on subsequent playthroughs the level ups could be saved or built to better accommodate that future class but for a first time playthrough this wasn’t very enjoyable to have happened.

[h1] Story [/h1]

While the story is very simple it is pretty engaging after a certain point. It starts on a ship that's been attacked and crashes on a planet, from there the player seeks out Bastila, a Jedi that was on the ship, as well as a way off. This first planet is focused on getting to Bastila and getting off the planet. For much of the early game, the only option for a companion is Carth, a republic soldier who isn’t very trusting and quite frankly is very annoying, after enough time more companions who are much better will be added. Following the departure of this planet is another tutorial to teach about the new class you get and from there the main plot revolves around stopping the Dark Lord Malak. Malak is not a very interesting villain, he is pretty evil without any real redeeming qualities or things to make him stand out, just a typical villain who wants power, as this fits with the main theme of Star Wars it isn’t too much of a negative.


[h1] Graphics [/h1]

The graphics are from 2003 so they are pretty outdated, however, they look nice enough for what they are despite some areas being very barren.

[h1] Soundtrack [/h1]

The soundtrack is really good, it features a few classic Star Wars tracks and overall great additions that fit well into Star Wars.

[h1] Conclusion [/h1]

Star Wars: Knights of the Old Republic is just ok. While it may have been good in 2003 20 years later it is a bit rough, not having the nostalgia may affect it more but the combat is rather boring and there are some design choices that don’t work well. All that being said the story and companions(for the most part) are very good and the music is good as well, if you’re able to get past the poor gameplay the game is alright but I don’t know if I’d recommend it, perhaps the remake if that ever happens will be more enjoyable.

[h1] Score: 5/10 [/h1]

Really wish the port was better. If bugs and memory overflow issues are problems that are too much for you, then I can't really recommend it in good faith.

The game itself, however, is fairly adequate by my standards, though I'm more of a jrpg fan. I can still definitely understand why it has the reputation it does, however. Doesn't have as much depth as I would like gameplay wise, but I really dug the story and presentation of the Star Wars universe in rpg format.

Overall, any frustrations and disappointments I had didn't really get in the way of my enjoyment, and while maybe not the most glowing praise, I think the novelty of this game is something most fans of Star Wars can have fun with despite its drawbacks.

131130607.review:
This game is what introduced me to the Star Wars universe. From a story-telling perspective, this is a masterpiece.

Right off the bat, the story is exciting and engaging. You are dropped right into the middle of a high-stakes space battle, and find yourself stranded on a foreign world where you must find allies to help you survive and complete your mission.
Every beat of the story adds a new complexity and exciting development to your journey, not to mention this game has the biggest and best plot twist I've ever seen in a video game. Never have I been so shocked by a video game.

The characters are good, but some lack the complexity of those in newer Bioware RPG's. The dialogue with some characters is extensive, while others don't have much to say.

The combat is fun, and force abilities feel truly devastatingly powerful. The only downside to gameplay is most "skills" aren't particularly useful, things like "security" and "computer use" can usually be handled by a party member; there isn't much point in your player character developing those.

Ultimately, this game is absolutely a must-play for anyone who likes story-driven games and that old-school Bioware magic.

130521583.review: I tried playing this game around 10 years ago.  After installation, I played it for about 4 hrs, and lost patience and uninstalled it. I thought the graphics were bad and it was slow. I lacked patience. My loss.  Fast forward to Christmas 2022, and after reading numerous positive reviews, I decided I would try it again, and I am so glad I did.  Sure, it's aged, the graphics are even worse compared to today's standards, but if you treat this like a story, an adventure, it's worth looking past the aged visuals and getting into it.  The plot is good, with a few twists, the voice acting is impeccable, the characters are fleshed out enough and rich, and the gameplay is pretty diverse too. In short, this is an excellent RPG. Play it once. It's well worth it.  I installed the community patch and the ultra widescreen to play it at 1920x1080, I also installed a mod that fixed the HUD items, which I recommend doing.  Highly recommended if you like star wars! 10/10.

130138697.review:
[i]Knights of the Old Republic[/i] is a beautifully realized game set in the immersive [i]Star Wars[/i] universe. The story, while predictable, is solid and every dialogue is fully voiced. The game's art design and music also contribute to the overall atmosphere of the game. In addition, the alien languages, while they can become annoying over time, add to the authenticity of the game's universe.

The game's choices may lack nuance, and the dark side options can be unnecessarily evil at times, but the overall role-playing experience is still enjoyable. The combat system, based on [i]Dungeons and Dragons[/i] 3rd edition, might not appeal to everyone but does not bother me, and it will be familiar to experienced CRPG players. However, it can still contribute to the clunkiness of the game.

Despite these issues, [i]Knights of the Old Republic[/i] is still a standout game for the franchise and is worth experiencing for fans of [i]Star Wars[/i] and CRPGs.

129818494.review:
Well, 20 years can do a lot to one's memory. It's a lot simpler, both in combat and in story structure, than I remember it being. It's a little rough in places, I kept getting caught on walls, and if you don't have V-sync on, sometimes your character refuses to move. And oh boy, do the mini-games suck. The space combat is a chore, the swoop racing later requires perfection for trivial rewards, and pazaak, well, I want to love lazy Star Wars blackjack but it's pretty boring. And for a game that was lauded for taking Star Wars out of the usual tiny part of a grand universe, it sure has a lot of connections to the movies. The trip to Tantooine is the most obvious, but there are items named after Calrissians, Fetts, Organas, etc. too. I guess they weren't willing to make a full break.

All that being said, I still loved it. The characters are fun, the story is grand and it feels like a great Star Wars adventure. Combat is simple but doesn't drag until the very end (when it gets repetitive), and I learned this time that the ending doesn't depend on your dark side/light side rating, rather on one choice you make near the end of the game, so you can be an awful human being who decides to save the world at the last minute and bam! Hero of the galaxy!

129382257.review:
Despite its pedigree, I'd say this game is more in the "good, but..." category of quality. It's the original Mass Effect but with a different combat system and a fixation on the Star Wars setting (or rather Mass Effect is KOTOR but with an original IP and therefore less Star Wars baggage). 

Its biggest strength is that it is very easy to simply play and make progress. Questing is clear and combat is approachable. It's also fairly dense and there are a decent amount of options in various narratives and systems. Though the gameplay isn't especially interesting in the moment, there is room for different builds and a persistent difficulty slider which allows for some nice leeway in case character builds don't turn out as effective as they should.

The downside is that the Star Wars universe's light side/dark side binary tends to rob the plot of a lot of complexity it should have otherwise. Characters can have interesting moral dilemmas, but framing those dilemmas as falling to the darkside defangs the interesting ways they could react to those problems. As well, despite the gameplay's capacity for depth, the in-moment choices aren't especially enthralling. 

That said, this is an easy game to just spend time with, especially if Star Wars aesthetics are sought after. Nothing about it is extraordinarily enjoyable and the characters aren't given as much love or focus as a game like Dragon Age: Origins, but it doesn't put too many negative elements in the way either and still manages to have some quality rpg elements to work with. One major recommendation though: invest in Force Speed. There is no sprint button and you will feel that absence otherwise. 

Tentative recommend.

129056269.review:
One of the greatest games in the Star Wars canon, Knights of the Old Republic brings the fictional universe to life as it had never been realized before, not just through its presentation but also its groundbreaking story.

Version played: Steam PC release with widescreen mod. Played on 2010 Mac Mini.
Play time: About 35 hours.
Gameplay: 85/100
Story: 95/100
Graphics and Design: 95/100
SFX/Audio/Music: 95/100
Fun factor: 92/100
Replay value: 90/100
Overall grade: 95/100

Pros / Cons Summary

Pros

• (Story) The story takes the light/dark alignment of the Jedi and makes it a feature of dialogue throughout the game.
• (Story) Plenty of humor in the story, especially thanks to the HK-47 combat droid. (Gameplay) A true RPG: your decisions affect your character and the way your companions perceive them.
• (Story) Your decisions can have big impacts on things in the galaxy.
• (Story) There's a classic twist, executed to perfection.
• (Story) The Star Forge concept is very cool and very Star Wars.
• (Story) Lots of companions to choose from depending on your taste and play style.
• (Gameplay) The combat is fun, especially when you start getting into using Force powers to kill your opponents.
• (Gameplay) It's fun to feel like either a powerful Jedi saving the galaxy or a dominant Sith crushing opposition.
• (Gameplay) Puzzles are reasonably difficult without being overly so.
• (Gameplay) No late-game difficulty spike. You should be more than powerful enough to defeat the final boss if you didn't rush.
• (Gameplay) Swoop racing is pretty fun.
• (Replay Value) Depending on how you play, endings differ greatly. This makes replaying the game very worthwhile.
• (Graphics and Design) Excellent designs show a de-evolved version of the Star Wars universe.
• (Graphics and Design) It's clear that the designers wanted to make an incredibly good game, and they took a lot of care with their craft.
• (SFX/Music) Jeremy Soule does a very good job with the music.
• (SFX/Music) Benefits a lot from using standard Star Wars sound effects.

Cons

• (Gameplay) I find character creation (class, skills, etc.) stressful and almost paralyzing.
• (Gameplay) Dice roll based combat makes wears thin when bashing doors.
• (Gameplay) Pazaak is not a well-designed or fair minigame.
• (Graphics and Design) There's no doubt the game is a bit dated at this point.
• (Graphics and Design) 
• (Audio) Points off for characters mispronouncing "Bastila."

128453614.review:
KotOR is both one of the best Star Wars games ever and best RPGs ever. KotOR introduced some of the most iconic Star Wars characters outside of the movies. The game certainly shows its age in 2022, however. Environments are often blank hallways and generic corridors, fields, forests, and caves. But, its old school Dungeons & Dragons game mechanics are engaging and the characters and storyline are more than enough to make up for it. KotOR excels at providing the quintessential Star Wars experience hitting all the tropes you love about the series with enough twists to keep it feeling like its own thing and creating an engaging and entertaining story. If you like Star Wars, D&D character sheets, Bioware writing, and MMO-like combat, KotOR is a must play.

AT LEAST IT WOULD BE if it worked. KotOR wasn't the most stable of games on any platform, but in 2022, on Steam, on Windows 11, it is hopelessly broken that I can't recommend even bothering. Between a crash-on-start bug, broken story triggers, graphical glitches, and random crashes, I can't get the game to work long enough to even beat it again.

If you are going to try playing it, you're going need one of if not all these fixes:
- Run in Windows XP compatibility mode
- Turn on Vsync
- Turn off frame buffers
- Turn off grass
- Install KotOR community patch
- Open swkotor.ini turn fullscreen to "=0"
- Write "AllowWindowedMode=1" under graphics options in the ini file
- Make several saves in multiple different save slots for emergency back ups to combat broken triggers
- Open swconfig.exe and disable movies if still crashes when trying to start new game; bye bye cutscenes

There's more fixes you can try to find with a google search. Good luck and may the force be with you. You'll need it.

128185160.review:
Great game, awful port.

Story still holds up to this day and it's clear that this game was an inspiration for BioWare to make the Mass Effect series.

Also, [spoiler]your custom character being revealed to be Darth Revan is intriguing as the aftermath you explore is a result of your character's carnage, with Revan acting as an extension of the player who has been given a clean slate; the results of which is their own decision[/spoiler].

For an RPG  made for the original Xbox in 2001, the gameplay still holds up quite well, albiet a little clunky. 
However, the PC port is filled with bugs and glitches, of which the most annoying ones are:
- Glitch after combat or cutscene that causes you to not be able to move. The only known fix for this is to save and then reload the save. 
- Cutscenes can sometimes cause the game to crash after too many transitions. Hope you saved!
- Combat actions on a party member are wiped and reset whenever the character is switched away from in combat. This means that if you are dealing with a swarm of enemies and have killed one, your turns are forfeit as you have to quickly re-select the actions.

It's a shame that this port is terrible as the company that ported the KotOR games, Aspyr, released a patch for the sequel that fixes the bugs present.

Bottom line that if you have to play this on PC, for the love of Pazaak, download a fan-made patch.

127312174.review:
I would never describe myself as a "gamer" but the pandemic gave me lots of time to fill so, as I'm a huge Star Wars fan, I decided to give this game a go based on all the amazing reviews.

And I really enjoyed getting through it!

It took me a little while to get used to the gameplay, and running back-and-forth on Taris working out what I needed to do.  But as the game evolved I got more and more into it.  Worked out better ways of managing the combat with all three characters, etc. 

The story is good.  Obvs it's an old game so questionable if it's all truly canon but it works.  I've only played through once so can only speak to the lightside path.  

There were a couple of bugs/glitches such as not getting the sword hilt on Kashyyyk so had to work out how to get that via a cheat code.  But otherwise fine

It's definitely got me playing more games and will try the sequel at some point.  Also interested how Disney will incorporate this era into their new canon - you hear/read about Revan now so feels good to be in the know - and then probably ruin it.

Okay, first off, HIGHLY recommend this game to anyone who hasn't played it, doesn't mind games like Dragon Age Origins or Mass Effect 1, which are very similar and distinct... so think of it like this: force powers are what got divided into DAO spells and ME1 abilities for Adepts later, guns/slicing and the like are just the ME1 and DAO abilities, enhanced. So, if you dislike either of these games and Star Wars in the title won't carry the whole experience, just don't bother.

Also, if you are on Windows 10, the game runs relatively fine, just set properties to launch it in compatibility for XP Service Pack 3. It'll make a great game playable, but be careful, it is older, and doesn't have the support KOTOR 2 does in workshop.

And yeah, if you like THIS game go to KOTOR 2 and Download the Mod for Missing Content before starting that. (Believe it's just called Restored Content, there's 2 versions, download the one that has the most stuff.)

NOW, I have to say something else to say about people without Windows 10 or relatively compatible OS's for this game. Get a Nintendo Switch, play it on there, then buy KOTOR 2 and do the above because KOTOR 2 is just better KOTOR 1. It's literally impossible to go wrong with these 2 games.

125816161.review:
IMPORTANT REVIEW FOR AMD GRAPHICS CARDS' USERS

I bought this game many years ago and, at the time, I was able to play it without issues. However, today, if you have AMD graphics card, I can't recommend this game. 

The game crashes constantly at certain points in the game, points that even prevent you from advancing in the story. After researching for hours and trying hundreds of solutions, I gave up. Apparently, it is very common for the game to crash on AMD cards.

If you don't use AMD, the game is great and will give you many hours of fun and a great story of one of the best Star Wars characters. But if you use AMD, it's not worth it, at least for now. Buy the game on Nintendo Switch or Android. Unironically, it runs better there than on AMD. When new AMD graphics patches are available, I will test if it runs correctly. If it works correctly, I will modify the review. 

I have read that downloading older AMD updates, specifically from before May 2022, allows the game to run smoothly. However, this solution does not work for me.

125247800.review:
9 out of 10 Misfits will enjoy this game.

First off, I want to say that this review is of the game itself.  I have played it fully on other consoles and beat it many times.  I also know that for me personally the game has never crashed on steam.  Others have had issues with it crashing, but I can only review what I have seen.

If you have never played the game (shame on you) than you have missed out on a great experience.  This is one of the best star wars games you will find anywhere.  From the story to the fighting to the characters this game hands down has it all.  Sure, the graphics aren't the best in the world, but the game is 20 years old (or around that) and when it released back then it was top notch graphics 100%.

The choices of play style in the game are great, you can be good or bad, you can use guns or light sabers (and the force of course), you can roleplay and find love, its all here.  This was definitely a defining game for the console and the times and even today remains one of the best games you can find.

If you love star wars, have never played the game (shame on you), or have played it before and want to jump back into it (who wouldn't) than this is definitely a great choice for a game and the price is really decent for the amount of content you get.

I first played this game in 2022 but played other BioWare titles before (Dragon Age Origins and the Mass Effect trilogy). This one lives up to the greatness of those or I should say those live up to this one since Kotor is older. The story is marvellous. A fully voice-acted game from 2003 when it was very much not an industry standard.
I liked the combat and people who played old RPGs before won't be surprised by the way it works but it is nearly 20 years old, so if it's the oldest game you ever played expect some clunkiness.
The developers flawlessly integrated the story to the known Star Wars universe but didn't overuse the places and known patterns of the films, you can find new things, places and reaces to experience.
All in all, this game deserves our praise in every aspect.

Su fama no la tiene por nada.

no niego que tiene algún que otro problema, en parte debido a ser un juego viejo, pero si buscas un poco encontraras mods y parches que pueden solucionarlos.

Pero si te da flojera como a mi, está igualmente recomendado, ya que lo pase sin ningún mod y aún sabiendo ciertos elementos de la historia de antemano, esta fue muy disfrutable.

Si tuviera que destacar algo seria primero que nada sus personajes, todos bastante bien desarrollados y con historias interesantes, reacciones creíbles y bastante carismáticos en su mayoría.
Otro punto a destacar es la historia en sí (que es de culto en esta saga) y también el mundo, lleno de personajes secundarios que nos darán mas historia y contexto, y misiones secundarias que bien puedes ignorar o completar para aprender mas del mundo y conseguir algunas recompensas.

Como detalle adicional, el hecho de que no tenga trofeos quita un poco la sensación de logro de pasar el juego, sin embargo también te aligera un poco la carga de querer completar el juego al 100%: terminarás disfrutando del juego sin importar que hayas avanzado más de la cuenta y hayas perdido alguna misión secundaria

123929883.review:
although this game has aged like a fine black mold on my psyche, i cannot recommend Star wars: Knights of the old republic, without understating how much of a banger this game is. Not only does it provide an excellent insight into the old republic, and how both the jedi and sith have changed over four millennia. The absolutely BANGING experience of going through this game's story, even spoiled, was a journey some could describe as "an epic that sucked my cock and re-affirmed my prejudice against hutts".
The good:
This game's story is a beast, with 30 hours of fucking around and interacting in the environment in a comfortable matter that will satisfy most players. All characters are likeable in some way and have a specific role in mind, serving a grand purpose in your playthrough. Although there is no way to influence the companions' alignment, I think that's for the best, because then i would just tailor my playthrough to manage dumbass numbers, and i hate that shit. Malak himself also get's extra points for being camp as fuck, i love that shit. The game also forces you to make meaningful choices with the planet quests as well, including the order of progress.
The bad:
Combat involves mainly slaughtering trash minions until you fight a unique enemy or tactical puzzle, which doesn't bother me all that much. it's always that battles against jedi or bosses that get me, especially because i dislike playing as soldier. Battles are unfamiliar to new players and i find it hard to recommend this game to people who want an action RPG rather than... whatever this is. 
The worst part of this game has to be getting a decent resolution to play it in. Since steam encrypts the EXE file, some end up cracking their game and causing many more problems down the line. This game hasn't had much help in terms of compatibility, unlike it's younger, edgier twin, so expect there to be problems on launch with the UI and other issues brought about by the buggy ass modified odyssey engine which this game relies on.
In conclusion: 
if you want to experience one of the classics that comforted me as i developed my autistic power, which i planned to use to summon my father with that coke cherry, you must heed any and all tutorials you can find, but beware, for if you are even a step off, the game WILL be off centre of your screen, and you will need a fresh install. my personal advice is to turn on winxp mode, run it in 800*600 ratio, run with admin and hope that your game doesn't decide to stop showing you that cutscene. 
Mods are not recommended, but that's up to you.

123803289.review:
"The Office" of the video game genre as far as replayability goes. I've been coming back to this game for nearly two decades now and it never gets old. Combat feels intuitive and you have a plethora of options on how to handle each encounter depending on your build/party composition. The cast is colorful and gives you plenty too chose from ranging from a hairy wookie to an assassin droid with a penchant for malevolence. The story is absolutely fantastic and stands head and shoulders over anything Disney has done with the franchise in the last decade. Ever if your not big on turn based games I'd still give it a shot as it's a very satisfying experience that doesn't demand much strategy if you just want to cruise through the game and enjoy the experience. Despite it coming out in 2003 it's aged very well, the graphics are a little dry compared to today's standard but the environments and character models still retains charm thanks to the simple semi-realistic art style. For 10 dollars or less the game is an absolute steal and you''ll get a good 20-30 hours of fun out of it. I also made a video on it if you want to get a good visual experience of what to expect of the game.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=iMORFdpzM04

123243321.review:
KOTOR tells a generic Star Wars story but it does it almost flawlessly, to such an extent that its seemingly pedestrian qualities make it among the most fun and accessible modern RPG experiences and Star Wars stories. 

The characters were one of the biggest highlights, enjoyable and memorable, making quests 10x more fun with their involvement and banter. As an RPG--particularly an early BioWare RPG--it took some shocking dares likes HK-47 (the basis for Mass Effect's Elcor species), but most prominently in the character of Jolee Bindo, whose entire presence--a good man sitting comfortably on the line between Dark Side and Light Side, quick to point out the flaws (and idiocy) of what the 'good' Jedi stand and die for--hints at the brilliant postmodern deconstruction Star Wars would get in Obsidian's ambitious sequel, and lets us know Karpshyn's not just some game-y buffoon with a bullet-point list of quest requirements above his desk and a bad grasp at avoiding familiar fetch quests in dialogue.

As an RPG born in 2003, it treads a line between oldschool and new-, with a strategic but accessible battle management system that lets you plan the course of battle at your own pace coupled with real-time decision-making and exciting action. Just with dice rolls. The leveling system is one of BioWare's most fluid and functional but you can, regrettably, get yourself stuck in a corner with bad decision-making.

I loved it!

Also, it says that one playthrough takes about 45 hours as a completionist but it took me almost 67. So either most people skip side quests and do not understand the meaning of the word completionist or I'm just slow. It was awesome either way.

123080928.review:
My English Comment

For a Star Wars fan like me, this game is fantastic. Although it is old, its graphics didn't bother me. I enjoyed playing it until the final battle of the game.
In the final battle of the game, our main villain uses tubes containing other force users to not die and to regenerate both his health and strength. No matter how hard we hit, when the final boss is about to die, he immediately regenerates and there is no end to it. It's impossible to break those tubes with a lightsaber. Throw lightning, use force push, throw your lightsaber, it doesn't matter. Tubes do not break. The only way (if I remember correctly) is to use the Stun Droid power. This power is also a power that can be obtained very easily. You can get this power at the beginning of the game if you want. But since this game is rpg and I didn't want to use this power in the game, it was one of the features I didn't get in the game. The save files of the game also belonged to the final war, so it was impossible for me to level up again and try to get that power. And those tubes just break with this stupid feature! 
That's why I couldn't finish the game... I watched the finale on Youtube... I tried for about 2 hours, I threw lightning bolts, I threw a lightsaber, but in vain. If you want to finish the game, get the Stun Droid feature at the beginning of the game.

If someone passed without the stun droid power, please let me know. Even in Dark Souls boss battles, I didn't have such a hard time.

--------------------------------------------------------------

-Türkçe Yorumum-

Benim gibi Star Wars hayranı birisi için bu oyun muhteşem. Eski olmasına rağmen grafikleri beni rahatsız etmedi. Çok keyif alarak oynadım ta ki oyunun final savaşına kadar. 
Oyunun final savaşında ana kötü karakterimiz ölmemek ve hem canını hemde gücünü yenilemek için başka force kullanıcılarının içinde olduğu tüpler kullanıyor. Biz ne kadar çok vursak da final boss ölecek gibi olduğunda hemen can yeniliyor ve bunun sonu yok. O tüpleri de ışın kılıcı ile kırmanız imkansız. Yıldırım atın, force push atın, ışın kılıcını atın farketmez. Tüpler kırılmıyor. Tek yolu (yanlış hatırlamıyorsam) stun droid gücünü kullanmak. Bu güç de gayet kolay elde edilebilen bir güç. Oyunun ilk başlarında bu gücü isterseniz alabilirsiniz. Ama bu oyun rpg olduğu için ve bu gücü kullanmayı oyunda istemediğim için oyundaki almadığım özelliklerden birisiydi. Oyunun save dosyaları da final savaşına aitti yani tekrardan level atlayıp o gücü almaya çalışmam imkansızdı. Ve o tüpler sadece bu aptal özellikle kırılıyor! Bu yüzden oyunu bitiremedim... Yaklaşık 2 saat denedim, şimşekler fırlattım, ışın kılıcı attım ama nafile. Siz siz olun oyunu bitirmek istiyorsanız Stun Droid özelliğini oyun başında alın.

Eğer Stun Droid kullanmadan final bossu geçen birisi varsa lütfen nasıl yapacağımı söylesin. Dark Souls boss dövüşlerinde bile bu kadar zorlanmadım...

I'm sure most people are thinking of getting this for nostalgia purposes. While for some of you it may be exactly as you remembered for most it won't be as good as you remember it being. When I first played this I thought it was one of the most advanced games I've ever seen. Now, after playing it again, it seems so incredibly basic that I was shocked. It's still a good game, don't get me wrong, but the quality of the game isn't up to current standards. You could find a better game, for the same price, easily.

If it was just that I'd say it's worth the $10 for people who want it for nostalgia purposes anyway. It's like the same as going to a movie but you'll get more hours played off it. The problem is that there's a lot of issues with the game; crashes, bugs, etc. For some people they can't even load the game without messing around with the settings (usually it's rendering issues). There's often a bug which stops you from moving and you have to reload the game to fix. For the quality of the game play + all the crashes/bugs I can't recommend this is worth $10. If you can get it for free, go for it. I was able to get it for free so I have no complaints... but this is a recommendation based on the current price.

122674791.review:
So right off the bat, before the review. I barely heard this game even exist ever, as I never grew up with an Xbox or PC. So a friend of mine bought the game while back and played it for a few hours just for the trip down memory lane. I was super interested in the game for the first few hours, as I noticed how interesting it was. Specially the Wizards of The Coast Third Edition of Dungeon & Dragons was heavily implied into it, which for a D&D nerd myself. I had to get the game as well. 

So for a 2003 game, it still holds up for its name. Though yes, the graphics and combat are a tad bit janky, of course outdated. Alongside the bugs that anyone could experience, some it would be worse and some would be bad. But for my experience sometimes when a cutscene begins; it just simply kicks me out of the game onto the windows page but it still runs. So I  had to open the tab back up for it to rerun the cutscene again. Sometimes there are bugs that happen, as if you run the game too long. Sometimes the dialogue goes mach 5, as if you are skipping through it. In reality, you didn’t touch anything for it to skip literal paragraphs of dialogue and expect you to answer right off the bat. Which would take a quick restart of the game to fix it. 

But for going into this game completely blind. The story is fantastic, as I was 100% blown away at such an interesting and original story with a huge arc and twist into it. Making me fall more in love with Star Wars (as I only watch the films and played the original battlefront games). The characters are really well thought out and interesting, as it is an RPG style game. Where choices do matter if it affects your character in both good, bad or just neutral. Though don’t expect much out of it, as you are either fighting for the good or the bad. The game itself is challenging and at times difficult, such as if you don’t focus on the right class or perks. You’re going through a tough time, such as my friend picking a scoundrel (rogue based stealth and thief) and consular (force focused jedi, who uses mainly the force than lightsaber combat). But he forced his character into combat and died non stop. 

Vs me, I did Soldier and Sentinel who was a dual wielding opponent who blew through certain levels like it’s nothing. But you can do whatever, such as being a jedi who uses a blaster all the way. So my official rating for it would be 8.5/10.

122659485.review: Great for anyone who enjoys Star Wars, specifically for immersing yourself into the world and having a character that has the story develop by your choices.

122656833.review:
KOTOR has an amazing story and is definitely worth a try if you like RPGs regardless of if you are a Star Wars fan. Since this game is set 4000 years before the events of the movie, the developers had almost complete creative freedom when it came to this game. The game also presents it's age really well, like for example the protocol droid has the same familiar design, but you can tell by the time of the movies, it had really progressed in its design. However, one complaint I do have is the combat system. I get what they were trying to do, a real time strategy type game but still an RPG. While the Combat system is unique, it's a little dumb. Like, I want to throw a grenade, but the character (If they have a melee weapon) would first go up and hit the enemy? I wanted you to throw a grenade from range not up close. 

Other than the combat system, solid 8.5/10.
